<a class="card-recipe-info" href="/recipes/1017825-twice-baked-butternut-squash-with-cashew-cheese-walnuts-and-cranberries" >
  <h3 class="name"
      data-name="Twice-Baked Butternut Squash With Cashew Cheese, Walnuts and Cranberries"
      data-share-title="Twice-Baked+Butternut+Squash+With+Cashew+Cheese%2C+Walnuts+and+Cranberries+by+Tara+Parker-Pope">
    Twice-Baked Butternut Squash With Cashew Cheese, Walnuts and Cranberries
  </h3>


    <p class="card-byline">By Tara Parker-Pope</p>

<script id="card-organize-tooltip" type="template">

  <div class="collections-container">
    <% if (!collections || !collections.length) { %>
      <div class="no-collections">
        You haven&#8217;t made any collections. Collections are a great way
        to make groupings of recipes for planning or creating menus.
      </div>
      <% } else { %>
        <div class="header">Add to:</div>
        <ul>
          <% collections.each(function(collection) { %>
            <% var containsRecipe = _.contains(savedCollections, collection.get('id')) ? 'contains-recipe' : ''; %>
            <li class="<%= containsRecipe %>" data-id="<%= collection.get('id') %>">
              <span class="name"><%= _.escape(collection.get('name')) %></span>
              <span class="check-mark"></span>
            </li>
          <% }); %>
        </ul>
      <% } %>
  </div>

  <div class="footer">
    <div class="create-collection">
      <div class="new-collection-button">
        <span class="new-text">New Collection</span>
      </div>
      <form class="new-collection-form removable">
        <input class="new-collection-input" autocomplete="off" placeholder="New collection name...">
        <span class="remove-icon"></span>
      </form>
    </div>
  </div>
</script>

    <div class='name-suggestion'>
      <%= name %>
      <% if(count) { %>
        <span class='recipe-count'>(<%= count %> Recipes)</span>
      <% } %>
    </div>
  </div>
</script>

</script>

<script id="simmer-card" type="template">
  <div class="simmer-card <% if (liked) { 'simmer-swipe-right' } else if (dismissed) { 'simmer-swipe-left' } %>" <% if (stack) { %>style="-webkit-transform: rotate(<%= rotation %>deg) translate3d(<%= translateX %>, <%= translateY %>, 0); transform: rotate(<%= rotation %>deg) translate3d(<%= translateX %>, <%= translateY %>, 0);" <% } %>>
    <div class="simmer-card-inner">
      <div class="simmer-image-wrap">
        <% if (cardImage) { %>
          <div class='image' style='background-image: url(<%= cardImage %>); background-size: cover; background-position: center center;'></div>
        <% } %>
      </div> <!-- /.image-wrap -->
      <div class="simmer-recipe-info">
        <h3 class="name"><%= name %></h3>

        <% if (byline) { %>
          <p class="simmer-byline">By <%= byline%></p>
        <% } %>

      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</script>


<script id="simmer-recipe-box" type="template">
<a class="<%= collectables.length > 0 ? 'simmer-recipe-box-populated' : 'simmer-recipe-box-empty' %>" href="/<%= user_id %>/recipe-box">Your Recipe Box (<%= collectables.length %>)</a>
</script>

<script id="simmer-intro" type="template">
  <h2><%= headline %></h2>
  <%= introText %>

  <div class="simmer-button-group">
    <button class="simmer-button simmer-button-intro simmer-everything" disabled="disabled">I like to cook everything</button>
    <button class="simmer-button simmer-button-intro simmer-healthy" disabled="disabled">I like to cook healthy food</button>
    <button class="simmer-button simmer-button-intro simmer-vegetarian" disabled="disabled">I like to cook vegetarian</button>
  </div>
  <a href="#" class="simmer-skip">Skip this for now</a>
</script>

  <% if (likedRecipes.length > 0) { %>

    <h2><%= headline %></h2>
    <%= introText %>

    <div class="simmer-button-group">
      <button class="simmer-save-button ladda-button" data-style="normal" data-spinner-size="24"><span class="icon-plus"></span>Save <%= recipeCount %></button>

    </header>

    </div>

    </div>

      <button class="btn-std simmer-dont-save-button">No thanks</button>
    </div>

</script>

<script id="note-tabs-tmpl" type="template">

  <% _.each(tabs, function(tab, index) { %>
    <% if (!tab.displayWhenNone && counts[index] == 0) return; %>
    <li class="<%= activeName === tab.name ? 'active' : '' %>">
      <a href="#" data-name="<%= tab.name %>"><%= tab.display %><span class="notes-count"><%= counts[index] %></span></a>
    </li>
  <% }); %>

</script>

<script id="note-tmpl" type="template">

  <div class="thread-note
      <%= isSameUserNote ? 'user-note' : '' %>
      <%= isPrivate ? 'private-note' : '' %>
      <%= canHaveReplies && isReply ? 'is-reply' : '' %>
      <%= isApproved ? '' : 'is-new' %>
      <%= wasJustAdded ? 'brand-new' : '' %>
      <%= isEditor ? 'editor-note' : '' %>"
      data-id="<%= id %>" data-user-id="<%= userId %>">
    <% if (!isApproved) { %>
      <div class="pending-note">
        Thank you for your submission. Your note will appear once it has been approved.
      </div>
    <% } %>
    <a class="note-img" href="<%= userUrl %>">
      <img class="user-img <%= imgSrc ? '' : 'hidden' %>" src="<%= imgSrc %>">
    </a>
    <div class="note-base">
      <div class="note-header">
        <a class="note-name" href="<%= userUrl %>"><%= userName %></a>
        <i class="icon-editor-badge <%= isEditor ? '' : 'hidden' %>"></i>
        <time class="note-time note-header-additional"><%= createTime %></time>
        <span class="note-private-msg note-header-additional">only you can see this</span>
      </div>
      <div class="note-body"><%= body %></div>
      <div class="note-footer">
        <% if (!isReply && canHaveReplies) { %>
          <div class="reply-btn">
            <i class="icon icon-reply-grey"></i>
            <i class="icon icon-reply-red"></i>
            Reply
          </div>
        <% } %>
        <div class="helpful-btn <%= isHelpful ? 'is-helpful' : '' %> ladda-button grey-spinner" data-style="normal" data-spinner-size="24">
          <i class="icon icon-thumbsup-grey-outline"></i>
          <i class="icon icon-thumbsup-yellow"></i>
          <span class="helpful-count"><%= recommendationsCount %></span>This is helpful
        </div>
      </div>

  </div>

var PREBID_TIMEOUT = 300;
var googletag = googletag || {};
googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error

})();

        <div class="lede-container">
            <figure id="media-100000003665230" class="media photo lede layout-jumbo-horizontal" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/04/opinion/tg-lede-sub/tg-lede-sub-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/04/opinion/tg-lede-sub/tg-lede-sub-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/04/opinion/tg-lede-sub/tg-lede-sub-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="&lt;a href=&quot;http://nyti.ms/1JkJf7D&quot;&gt;Graham Bridgeman&lt;/a&gt;" data-mediaviewer-credit="Damon Winter/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/04/opinion/tg-lede-sub/tg-lede-sub-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="753" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text"><a href="http://nyti.ms/1JkJf7D">Graham Bridgeman</a></span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Damon Winter/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
            <div class="lede-container-ads">
                                                                            </div>
        </div>

        <div id="byline-sharetools-container" class="byline-sharetools-container">
                                            </div>


                
        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="157" data-total-count="157" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1"><em>Being transgender today is still unreasonably hard, but it is far from hopeless. This is the first in a series of editorials looking at the challenges ahead.</em></p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="493" data-total-count="650" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">A generation ago, transgender Americans were widely regarded as deviants, unfit for dignified workplaces, a disgrace for families. Those who confided in relatives were, by and large, pitied and shunned. For most, transitioning on the job was tantamount to career suicide. Medical procedures to align a person’s body with that person’s gender identity — an internal sense of being male, female or something else — were a fringe specialty, available only to a few who paid out of pocket.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="48" data-total-count="698" itemprop="articleBody">Coming out meant going through life as a pariah.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-3">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="507" data-total-count="1205" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">Being transgender today remains unreasonably and unnecessarily hard. But it is far from hopeless. More Americans who have wrestled with gender identity are transitioning openly, propelling <a title="National Center for Transgender Equality" href="http://transequality.org/">a civil rights movement</a> that has struggled even as gays and lesbians have reached irreversible momentum <a title="NYT editorial " href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/29/opinion/a-landmark-gay-marriagecase-at-the-supreme-court.html">in their fight for equality</a>. Those coming out now are doing so with trepidation, realizing that while pockets of tolerance are expanding, discriminatory policies and hostile, uninformed attitudes remain widespread.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="224" data-total-count="1429" itemprop="articleBody">They deserve to come out in a nation where stories of compassion and support vastly outnumber those that end with a suicide note. The tide is shifting, but far too slowly, while lives, careers and dreams hang in the balance.</p><figure id="trans-quote" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <script>function getFlexData() { return {"data":{"quote":"“The only way I will rest in peace is if one day transgender people aren’t treated the way I was, they’re treated like humans.”","attribution":"Leelah Alcorn, a 17-year-old, in her suicide note. "}}; }var NYTD=NYTD || {}; NYTD.FlexTypes = NYTD.FlexTypes || []; NYTD.FlexTypes.push({"target":"FT100000003661529","type":"Pull Quote","data":{"quote":"“The only way I will rest in peace is if one day transgender people aren’t treated the way I was, they’re treated like humans.”","attribution":"Leelah Alcorn, a 17-year-old, in her suicide note. "}});</script><link href="http://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2015/02/10/mag-pullquote-redesign/assets/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">

<script>
  var NYTG_ASSETS = "http://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2015/02/10/mag-pullquote-redesign/b585ac490ed3103c57423bc4f581ffac30ebc5df/",
      NYTG_BIG_ASSETS = "http://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2015/02/10/mag-pullquote-redesign/assets/",
      _gaq = _gaq || [];

    require(["http://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2015/02/10/mag-pullquote-redesign/assets/build.js"]); // generated from src/script.js
  });
</script><div id="FT100000003661529"></div>    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="770" data-total-count="2199" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">Many of the heartening stories have unfolded out of sight. Some employers in the public and private sectors have begun to openly support people making the transition. At the Central Intelligence Agency, a young analyst who transitioned on the job in 2013 worried that coming out would end her career. She realized that fear was unfounded when colleagues got her a gift certificate to Ann Taylor after she transitioned at work and senior agency officials made it their mission to ensure she could continue to thrive at her job. Yet at the same time, thousands of American troops who are transgender <a title="Report of the Transgender Military Service Commission" href="http://www.palmcenter.org/files/Transgender%20Military%20Service%20Report_0.pdf">serve in anguish</a> because the military bans openly transgender people from joining the service. Those who take steps to transition can be discharged under the current rules.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="509" data-total-count="2708" itemprop="articleBody">In several states, transgender people are courageously battling efforts to bar them from using public restrooms. In West Virginia, transgender women have been at war with the Division of Motor Vehicles because <a title="TLDEF link " href="http://www.transgenderlegal.org/headline_show.php?id=476">officials are refusing</a> to give them new licenses unless they stop “misrepresenting” their gender when they have their photo taken. A recent federal government survey found that one in five transgender people reported having been denied care by a health care provider as a result of their gender.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="264" data-total-count="2972" itemprop="articleBody">These indignities and abuse account for the alarmingly high rates of homelessness, unemployment and suicide for transgender people. <a title="NYT op-ed" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/07/opinion/a-response-to-leelah-alcorns-suicide-note.html">Leelah Alcorn</a>, a 17-year-old from Ohio, wrote a harrowing suicide letter before leaping in front of a tractor-trailer last December.</p><figure id="media-100000003661765" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003661765 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/03/opinion/tg-image/tg-image-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/03/opinion/tg-image/tg-image-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/03/opinion/tg-image/tg-image-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="&lt;a href=&quot;http://nyti.ms/1OTH5CQ&quot;&gt;J Mase III&lt;/a&gt;" data-mediaviewer-credit="Damon Winter/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/03/opinion/tg-image/tg-image-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text"><a href="http://nyti.ms/1OTH5CQ">J Mase III</a></span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Damon Winter/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="173" data-total-count="3145" itemprop="articleBody">“The only way I will rest in peace is if one day transgender people aren’t treated the way I was, they’re treated like humans,” <a title="Link to Slate " href="http://www.slate.com/blogs/outward/2014/12/31/leelah_alcorn_transgender_teen_from_ohio_should_be_honored_in_death.html">she wrote</a>. “Fix society. Please.”</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-5">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="631" data-total-count="3776" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-5">Three years before a police <a title="NYT link " href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/s/stonewall_rebellion/index.html">raid of the Stonewall Inn</a> in New York in June 1969 galvanized the gay rights movement in America, <a title="Link to The Advocate " href="http://www.advocate.com/politics/transgender/2012/08/23/watch-march-honor-46th-anniversary-compton-cafeteria-riots">transgender women rioted</a> after being expelled from Compton’s Cafeteria in San Francisco. The restaurant had become one of the few safe gathering spots for the city’s community of transgender people, who at the time were not welcome at gay bars. That same year, physician Harry Benjamin published “<a title="Link to manuscript " href="http://www.mut23.de/texte/Harry&">The Transsexual Phenomenon,</a>” a groundbreaking book that outlined how transgender people could transition medically. The two developments helped give rise to an arduous fight for societal acceptance.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="659" data-total-count="4435" itemprop="articleBody">Over the decades, the transgender movement has been part of the broader quest for equality for sexual minorities, but while gays and lesbians have achieved far-reaching <a title="NYT editorial " href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/27/opinion/the-same-sex-marriage-rulings.html">legal and political victories</a> in recent years, transgender people, who may be gay or straight, remain among <a title="Link to Injustice at Every Turn " href="http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_full.pdf">the nation’s most marginalized citizens</a>. They face distinct challenges, including access to transition-related medical care, which have not always been a focus of the broader struggle for gay rights. Gays and lesbians are visible in all walks of life today, and many are celebrities and role models. Transgender Americans, meanwhile, remained largely unseen until fairly recently.</p><figure id="tg-storywall-promo" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">

<aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-6">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="665" data-total-count="5100" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-6">As prominent transgender people have come out in recent years, their revelations have been a source of fascination, much of it prurient. There was the actress Laverne Cox, the Army whistle-blower <a title="Link to Twitter account " href="https://twitter.com/xychelsea">Chelsea Manning</a> and most recently, <a title="ABC News link " href="http://abcnews.go.com/topics/entertainment/actors/bruce-jenner.htm">Bruce Jenner</a>, the gold-medal Olympian. Their stories have brought attention to the plight of a segment of the population that continues to confound many Americans. One challenge lies in semantics, a complex and fraught subject given the extraordinary diversity of experiences within the transgender community. The term transgender covers a broad range of people who do not identify with the gender listed on their birth certificate.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="325" data-total-count="5425" itemprop="articleBody">Scientists have no conclusive explanation for what causes some people to feel dissonance between their gender identity and aspects of their anatomy. In 2013, the American Psychiatric Association <a title="Link to GLAAD website " href="http://www.glaad.org/blog/apa-removes-gender-identity-disorder-updated-mental-health-guide">updated its manual</a>, replacing the term “gender identity disorder,” with one that is less stigmatizing, “gender dysphoria.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="784" data-total-count="6209" itemprop="articleBody">The options for those who take steps to ease the distress has expanded significantly in recent years. Some opt to wear clothes typically associated with the sex they identify with, legally change their names and use new pronouns. Many also undergo hormone replacement therapy and have surgery to transform their bodies. Surgical procedures include chest reduction and augmentation as well as sex-reassignment surgery. Some people have just one type of procedure, others undergo both, and some choose to have none. While many transgender people identify with one gender, some feel their identity lies somewhere in between. The spectrum of experiences and identities is complicated, but taking basic steps to ensure that more transgender people lead healthy and fulfilling lives is not.</p><figure id="trans-quote2" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-7">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">

<div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-7">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="467" data-total-count="6676" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-7">Expanded formal recognition is a fundamental first step. The size of the transgender community in America has always been unclear, since many people wrestle with gender dysphoria in silence. The most widely-cited figure, 700,000, comes from a <a title="Williams Institute link" href="http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/research/census-lgbt-demographics-studies/how-many-people-are-lesbian-gay-bisexual-and-transgender/">2011 study by the Williams Institute</a> at the University of California, Los Angeles. The United States Census Bureau should give transgender Americans the chance to be formally recognized as such on forms, if they choose to.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-8">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="568" data-total-count="7244" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-8">Having more detailed information about the demographics of the population is crucial to the evolution of stronger legal protections and expanded access to health care. There has been significant progress on both fronts. Last year, Medicare, which has a big influence on the industry standard for insurance coverage, <a title="NYT editorial link " href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/10/opinion/progress-on-transgender-rights-and-health.html">lifted its ban on covering gender reassignment surgery</a>. More states and insurance providers are following that lead, heeding the call of medical experts who say transgender-related care must be viewed as “medically necessary,” rather than elective.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="571" data-total-count="7815" itemprop="articleBody">There have been hard-won victories on the employment front, too. The <a title="Department of Justice link " href="http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/attorney-general-holder-directs-department-include-gender-identity-under-sex-discrimination">Department of Justice last year </a> began taking the position that discrimination on the basis of gender identity, including transgender status, constitutes sex discrimination under the Civil Rights Act. That memo adds to the growing body of case law and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission rulings that have strengthened legal protections for transgender workers. Yet, many jurisdictions lack local laws that protect transgender people and discrimination remains commonplace even in places that do.</p><figure id="trans-quote3" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <script>function getFlexData() { return {"data":{"quote":"This generation should be the one that stopped thinking that being transgender is something to fear or shun.","attribution":""}}; }var NYTD=NYTD || {}; NYTD.FlexTypes = NYTD.FlexTypes || []; NYTD.FlexTypes.push({"target":"FT100000003664103","type":"Pull Quote","data":{"quote":"This generation should be the one that stopped thinking that being transgender is something to fear or shun.","attribution":""}});</script><link href="http://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2015/02/10/mag-pullquote-redesign/assets/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">

  var NYTG_ASSETS = "http://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2015/02/10/mag-pullquote-redesign/b585ac490ed3103c57423bc4f581ffac30ebc5df/",

    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="336" data-total-count="8151" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-9">President Obama has advanced transgender rights more than any American president. But there is a glaring form of discrimination that he has the power to end. The Pentagon continues to ban openly transgender people from joining the military, even though many of America’s closest allies have integrated them seamlessly in recent years.</p><figure id="tg-notifications-signup-int" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-10">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">

	color: inherit;
}
#notification-widget .button:hover {
	background-color: #ef1f80;
}
#notification-widget .button:first-child {
	width: auto;
	border-top-left-radius: 3px;
	border-bottom-left-radius: 3px;
}
#notification-widget div.error {
	font-family: 'nyt-franklin', Helvetica, sans-serif;
	color: #FF9859;
  font-size: 12px;
  margin-top: 5px;
}
.notification-signup span {
	font-size: 14px;
  color: #333;
  font-family: 'nyt-franklin', Helvetica, sans-serif;
  font-weight: 600;
}
.notification-signup a {
	font-size: 14px;
  font-family: 'nyt-franklin', Helvetica, sans-serif;
  font-weight: 400;
  margin-top: 10px;
  display: block;
}
#notification-widget div[data-status='working'] button {
	position: relative;
}
#notification-widget div[data-status='working'] button span{
	visibility: hidden;
}
#notification-widget div[data-status='working'] button:after{
	content: '';
	display: block;
	opacity: 0.7;
	border: 5px dashed white;
	border-radius: 50%;
	width: 10px;
	height: 10px;
	position: absolute;
	top: 50%;
	left: 50%;
  margin-top: -9px;
  margin-left: -9px;
  -webkit-animation: spin 0.5s linear infinite;
  -moz-animation: spin 0.5s linear infinite;
  -o-animation: spin 0.5s linear infinite;
  animation: spin 0.5s linear infinite;
}
@-webkit-keyframes spin {
  from { -webkit-transform: rotate(0deg); }
    to { -webkit-transform: rotate(360deg); }
}
@-moz-keyframes spin {
  from { -moz-transform: rotate(0deg); }
    to { -moz-transform: rotate(360deg); }
}
@keyframes spin {
  from {transform:rotate(0deg); }
    to {transform:rotate(360deg); }
}</style>

<div id="g-graphic" class="notification-signup">
	<h3 class="notifications-title">Sign up for email updates</h3>
	<p class="notification-text">Tell me when the next installments of “Transgender Today” are available.</p>
  <div id="notification-widget"><!-- you can't put anything in here --></div>
</div>

<script>
  var NYTG_ASSETS = "http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/04/24/tg-notifications-signup/69bb375bb73383e46c0b519e19739a53f3dfbeab/",
      NYTG_BIG_ASSETS = "http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/04/24/tg-notifications-signup/assets/",
      _gaq = _gaq || [];
  require(['foundation/main'], function() {
    require(["http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/04/24/tg-notifications-signup/69bb375bb73383e46c0b519e19739a53f3dfbeab/build.js"]); // generated from src/script.js
  });
</script>

<script>
require.config({
  paths: {
    'nytint/email-subscriber' : 'http://int.nyt.com/applications/email-subscriber/client'
  }
});

require(['foundation/main'], function() {
  require(['nytint/email-subscriber'], function(Subscriber) {
    Subscriber.setup({ containerId: 'notification-widget', productCode: 'TG' });
  });
});
</script><!-- Pipeline: 2015-04-24-tg-notifications-signup | August 3, 2015, 04:36PM | 69bb375bb73383e46c0b519e19739a53f3dfbeab -->
    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="331" data-total-count="8482" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-10">The lack of legal protections and access to necessary care in the military system has made thousands of transgender troops extraordinarily vulnerable. <a title="Washington Post link " href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/for-transgender-service-members-concept-of-dont-ask-dont-tell-remains-a-reality/2014/04/26/c0597936-ccb6-11e3-93eb-6c0037dde2ad_story.html">Some have been discharged</a> for being transgender, while others have opted to quit, forgoing pensions and career advancement, because delaying their transition has become unbearable.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="605" data-total-count="9087" itemprop="articleBody">At the Department of Defense, a handful of senior officials have quietly met with <a title="Link to SPARTA web site " href="http://www.spartapride.org/">active duty transgender troops</a> to study how that segment of the force could serve openly. The officials have become convinced that lifting the ban would unlock the service members’ unfulfilled potential. Defense Secretary Ashton Carter should ask these officials to lead a swift review of the steps the Pentagon needs to take to formally integrate transgender troops. While that review is underway, Mr. Carter should instruct service chiefs to stop expelling transgender troops who are in the process of being discharged.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="274" data-total-count="9361" itemprop="articleBody">A generation from now, scientists will most likely know more about gender dysphoria and physicians will undoubtedly have found better ways to help people transition. This generation should be the one that stopped thinking that being transgender is something to fear or shun.</p>
        
                                        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
                <div class="story-notes"><p>Typography by Leonardo Sonnoli</p><p>Follow The New York Times Opinion section on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion">Facebook</a> and <a href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion">Twitter</a>, and sign up for the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/opiniontoday/">Opinion Today newsletter</a>.</p></div>
        
        
        <p class="story-print-citation">A version of this editorial appears in print on May 4, 2015, on page A22 of the <span itemprop="printEdition">New York edition</span> with the headline: The Quest for Transgender Equality. <span class="story-footer-links">  <span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/todayspaper/index.html" target="_blank">Today's Paper</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span><span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/subscriptions/Multiproduct/lp839RF.html?campaignId=48JQY" target="_blank">Subscribe</a></span>
</span>
</p>
    </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </footer>

        
            </div><!-- close story-body -->
</article>

<article id="story" class="story theme-interactive 
    theme-main 
    ">
                
    <header class="story-header interactive-header">
                        <div class="story-meta">
                            <button class="button comments-button  theme-kicker" data-skip-to-para-id="">
</button>
                                    <div class="kicker-container">
                <h2 class="kicker interactive-kicker">
                                        <span class="kicker-label">
                        <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/sports/index.html">
                            Sports                        </a>
                    </span>
                                                                            </h2>
                                    <div id="sharetools-interactive" aria-label="tools" role="group" class="sharetools theme-classic  sharetools-interactive  "
data-shares="show-all|Share"
data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/04/16/sports/errors-in-inquiry-on-rape-allegations-against-fsu-jameis-winston.html"
data-title="Errors in Inquiry on Rape Allegations Against FSU’s Jameis Winston"
data-author=""
data-media="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/04/15/sports/fsu-case-1397611855519/fsu-case-1397611855519-jumbo.jpg"
data-description="An accusation against Jameis Winston, a marquee quarterback for Florida State, did not prompt an in-depth inquiry by either the university or the police. By the time prosecutors got the case it was nearly a year old."
	data-publish-date="April 16, 2014"
>
<div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
</div>
</div><!-- close shareTools -->
                            </div>
                                    <h1 class="story-heading interactive-headline" itemprop="headline">Errors in Inquiry on Rape Allegations Against FSU’s Jameis Winston</h1>
            
            <div class="story-meta-footer interactive-meta-footer">
                                 <p class="interactive-leadin summary">
    
        			        	<time class="dateline" datetime="2014-04-16" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-04-16">APRIL 16, 2014</time>
	    	                                </p>
            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->

        </div><!-- close story-meta -->
        </header>
    <div id="errors-in-inquiry-on-rape-allegations-against-fsu-jameis-winston" class="interactive-graphic">
        <!-- 
 
======================================================
 
THIS IS A GENERATED TEMPLATE FILE. DO NOT EDIT.
 
======================================================
 
-->
 <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2014/04/13/florida-state/4b0b0c02b74546e00265cd5b0e0862acba2c4ead/build.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2014/04/13/florida-state/4b0b0c02b74546e00265cd5b0e0862acba2c4ead/resizerStyle.css">

<div id="g-container" class="g-container">
  
<!--   <div class="g-sharetools g-sharetools-slim" data-shares="facebook|Facebook,twitter|Twitter"></div> -->

  <div class="g-header-wrap" style="background-image: url(http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2014/04/13/florida-state/assets/images/potbellys-top-1564.jpg);">
  
		<div class="user-tools clearfix">
			<div class="g-sharetools g-sharetools-all" data-shares="show-all|Share"><div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad hidden"></div></div>
			<div class="g-comments-button comments-button button-masthead"><i class="icon"></i> <span class="button-text no-comments"> <span class="default">Comment</span> </span></div>
		</div>
  
    <div class="g-logo-wrap">
    <a class="nyt-logo" href="//www.nytimes.com" title="The New York Times">
      <svg width="185" height="26" role="img" aria-label="The New York Times">
        <image width="185" height="26" xlink:href="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2014/04/13/florida-state/assets/nyt-logo-185x26.svg" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2014/04/13/florida-state/assets/nyt-logo-185x26.png" alt="The New York Times" border="0"></image>
      </svg>
    </a>
    </div>
    <h2 class="g-headline">A Star Player Accused, and a Flawed Rape Investigation</h2>
    <h1 class="g-search-headline">Errors in Inquiry on Rape Allegations Against F.S.U.'s Jamies Winston</h1>
    <p class="g-byline">By <span class="g-caps">WALT BOGDANICH</span></p>
    <p class="g-timestamp">April 16, 2014</p>
  </div>
  <div class="g-image g-header-caption">
    <p class="g-caption">Florida State University students at Potbelly’s, where a student had been drinking on the night she said she was raped. <span class="g-credit">Leslye Davis/The New York Times</span></p>
  </div>

  <div class="g-article">

    <!-- #g-header -->
    
    <div class="g-body-container g-clearfix">
          
    <!-- <p class="g-dateline">Tallahassee, Fla.</p> -->

<p class="first-graf"><b>Tallahassee, Fla. &#151; Early on the morning of Dec. 7, 2012, a freshman at Florida State University reported that she had been raped by a stranger somewhere off campus after a night of drinking at a popular Tallahassee bar called Potbelly’s.</b></p>

<p>As she gave her account to the police, several bruises began to appear, indicating recent trauma. Tests would later find semen on her underwear.</p>

<p>For nearly a year, the events of that evening remained a well-kept secret until the woman’s allegations burst into the open, roiling the university and threatening a prized asset: Jameis Winston, one of the marquee names of college football.</p>

<p>Three weeks after Mr. Winston was publicly identified as the suspect, the storm had passed. The local prosecutor announced that he lacked the evidence to charge Mr. Winston with rape. The quarterback would go on to win the Heisman Trophy and lead Florida State to the national championship.</p>

      <div id="g-image-winston-football"></div>


<p>In his announcement, the prosecutor, William N. Meggs, acknowledged a number of shortcomings in the police investigation. In fact, an examination by The New York Times has found that there was virtually no investigation at all, either by the police or the university.</p>

<p>The police did not follow the obvious leads that would have quickly identified the suspect as well as witnesses, one of whom videotaped part of the sexual encounter. After the accuser identified Mr. Winston as her assailant, the police did not even attempt to interview him for nearly two weeks and never obtained his DNA.</p>

<p>The detective handling the case waited two months to write his first report and then prematurely suspended his inquiry without informing the accuser. By the time the prosecutor got the case, important evidence had disappeared, including the video of the sexual act.</p>

<p>“They just missed all the basic fundamental stuff that you are supposed to do,” Mr. Meggs said in a recent interview. Even so, he cautioned, a better investigation might have yielded the same result.</p>

<p>The case has unfolded as colleges and universities across the country are facing rising criticism over how they deal with sexual assault, as well as questions about whether athletes sometimes receive preferential treatment. The Times’s examination — based on police and university records, as well as interviews with people close to the case, including lawyers and sexual assault experts — found that, in the Winston case, Florida State did little to determine what had happened.</p>

      <div id="g-video-meggs"></div>


<p>University administrators, in apparent violation of federal law, did not promptly investigate either the rape accusation or the witness’s admission that he had videotaped part of the encounter.</p>

<p>Records show that Florida State’s athletic department knew about the rape accusation early on, in January 2013, when the assistant athletic director called the police to inquire about the case. Even so, the university did nothing about it, allowing Mr. Winston to play the full season without having to answer any questions. After the championship game, in January 2014, university officials asked Mr. Winston to discuss the case, but he declined on advice of his lawyer.</p>

<p>When The Times asked Mr. Winston for an interview, an Atlanta lawyer advising his family, David Cornwell, responded, “We don’t need an investigation, thorough or otherwise, to know that Jameis did not sexually assault this young lady.” Mr. Cornwell, who has represented major sports figures and the N.F.L., added, “Jameis has never sexually assaulted anybody.”</p>

<p>Mr. Winston has previously acknowledged having sex with his accuser but said it was consensual. His account has been supported by two friends from the football team who were with him that night, Chris Casher, who took the video, and Ronald Darby.</p>

<p>A month before the rape accusation became public, the university’s victim advocate learned that a second woman had sought counseling after a sexual encounter with Mr. Winston, according to the prosecutor’s office. The woman did not call it rape — she did not say “no.” But the encounter, not previously reported, “was of such a nature that she felt violated or felt that she needed to seek some type of counseling for her emotions about the experience,” according to Georgia Cappleman, the chief assistant state attorney, who said she had spoken with the advocate but not with the woman.</p>

<p>The victim advocate was concerned enough about the episode to have alerted Mr. Winston’s first accuser. </p>

<p>Ms. Cappleman said that based on what she was told, a crime had not been committed. Nonetheless, Ms. Cappleman said she found the encounter troubling, because it “sheds some light on the way Mr. Winston operates” and on what may be “a recurring problem rather than some type of misunderstanding that occurred in an isolated situation.”</p>

<p>Mr. Cornwell called her comments “out of bounds,” adding, “I’m not interested in a prosecutor expressing an opinion based on a personal moral compass.”</p>


<div class="g-graphic g-graphic-timeline">
  <h3 class="g-graphic-hed">How Long It Took to Gather Key Evidence</h3>
  <p class="g-body">Investigators showed little interest in finding out what happened. They delayed talking to witnesses, interviewing Mr. Winston and collecting his DNA.</p>
  <div class="g-timeline-mask">
    <div class="g-line"></div>
    <div class="g-swipe">&#8592; <span>Swipe</span> <span>&#8594;</span></div>
    <div class="g-timeline-events g-clearfix">
    
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-label g-clearfix year" style="top: 21.367521367521363%">
        <p class="g-label">2012<br>2013</p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-label g-clearfix gap" style="top: 71.79487179487177%">
        <p class="g-label">Nine months pass</p>
      </div>
      
    
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 0%">
        <p class="g-date">Dec. 7</p>
        <div class="g-marker"></div>
        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-hide"></span>
          <span class="g-subhed">Accuser tells police:</span> A Florida State University student told police she was raped that morning after drinking at Potbelly’s, a popular local bar.
        </p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 29.059829059829053%">
        <p class="g-date">Jan. 10</p>
        <div class="g-marker"></div>
        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-show">34 days</span>
          <span class="g-subhed">Identify Mr. Winston:</span> Police failed to identify Mr. Winston, learning his identity only after the accuser recognized him on campus and told police.
        </p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 40.17094017094016%">
        <p class="g-date">Jan. 23</p>
        <div class="g-marker"></div>
        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-show">47 days</span>
          <span class="g-subhed">Contact Mr. Winston:</span> Tallahassee police investigators waited nearly two weeks before trying to contact Mr. Winston.
        </p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 56.4102564102564%">
        <p class="g-date">Feb. 11</p>
        <div class="g-marker"></div>
        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-show">66 days</span>
          <span class="g-subhed">Close case:</span> Scott Angulo, the lead investigator, filed his first report, closing the case without interviewing crucial witnesses or getting DNA or phone records from Mr. Winston.
        </p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 82.05128205128206%">
        <p class="g-date">Nov. 14</p>
        <div class="g-marker"></div>
        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-show">342 days</span>
          <span class="g-subhed">Interview key witness:</span> For the first time, investigators interviewed a football player who witnessed sex between Mr. Winston and the accuser. <br><span class="g-subhed">Obtain DNA sample:</span> Investigators obtained Mr. Winston’s DNA that matches DNA found on the accuser's clothing.
        </p>
      </div>
      
      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 100%">
        <p class="g-date">Dec. 5</p>
        <div class="g-marker"></div>
        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-show">363 days</span>
          <span class="g-subhed">No prosecution:</span> The local prosecutor William N. Meggs decided the evidence was not sufficient to prosecute Mr. Winston.
        </p>
      </div>
      
      
    </div>

      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 40.17094017094016%">

          <span class="g-count g-show">66 days</span>

      <div class="g-event g-event-event g-clearfix " style="top: 100%">

        <p class="g-text">
          <span class="g-count g-show">363 days</span>

        </p>

    </div>
