		<header class="story-header">
		<h1 itemprop="headline" class="story-heading entry-title"><span>New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers</span></h1>		<div class="story-meta entry-meta">
			<span class="author vcard byline-author"
					itemscope=""
					itemprop="author creator"
					itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
					By <span class="fn" itemprop="name">James Estrin</span>
				</span><!-- date published --><time class="dateline " datetime="2014-04-14T19:05:21+00:00" itemprop="datePublished">Apr. 14, 2014</time>
			<!-- date updated --><span class="visually-hidden updated">Apr. 14, 2014</span><span class="postMetaHeaderCommentCount commentCount hidden">
					<i class="icon"></i>
					<a class="commentCountLink commentCountNumberOnly" href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/14/the-new-york-times-wins-two-photography-pulitzers/"></a>
				</span>		</div>
	</header>
	<div class="shareTools sharetools layout-vertical" data-shares="email|Email,facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet,save|Save,show-all|More,ad" data-url="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/14/the-new-york-times-wins-two-photography-pulitzers/" data-title="New York Times Wins Two Photography Pulitzers" data-description="The Times swept the 2014 prizes for photography. Tyler Hicks won for his coverage of a terrorist attack at a Nairobi mall. Josh Haner was honored for his images of the slow and painful recovery process of a Boston Marathon bombing survivor. "><div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad"></div></div>	<div class="post-content">
				<script>
			if ( window.innerWidth < 975 ) {
				document.write( '<div class="module ad" id="MiddleRight"></div>' );
			}
		</script>
		<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">The New York Times has swept the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes for photography. The staff photographer <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/h/tyler_hicks/index.html">Tyler Hicks</a> won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for his coverage of a <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2013/09/21/world/africa/20130922_NAIROBI2_337-1.html?_r=1&amp;">terrorist attack</a> at an upscale mall in Nairobi, Kenya, that left more than 60 people dead. <a href="http://www.joshhaner.com/">Josh Haner</a> was awarded the Pulitzer in feature photography for his images of the slow and painful recovery process for a <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/08/sports/beyond-the-finish-line.html?slide=20130708_BAUMAN-slide-3TSI&amp;name=bauman">survivor of the Boston Marathon bombing</a>.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">The announcement was made on Monday by Columbia University, which bestows the awards.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“For me it’s a symbol of what we do at the newspaper as a whole — the best of foreign reporting and the best of our enterprise,” said Michele McNally, the paper’s assistant managing editor for photography. “It is recognition that our photojournalism is on par with the quality of The New York Times’s reporting, which is the best in the world.”</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">This is the second time that the Times has won both Pulitzer photography prizes in the same year. In 2002 The Times won in breaking news for a portfolio of work by 15 photographers who covered the events of Sept. 11, 2001, and the feature award for five photographers&#8217; work in Pakistan and Afghanistan after those attacks.</p>
<div class="w165 left module">
<div class="entry">
<h6 class="kicker">Showcase</h6>
<h5>Tyler Hicks</h5>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2014/04/10/world/africa/WESTGATE.html#1"><img class="w165" alt="DESCRIPTION" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B1K2/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B1K2-custom1.jpg" /></a></p>
<p class="summary">A look back on Mr. Hicks&#8217;s work on Lens.</p>
<ul class="refer">
<li><a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/21/witness-to-a-massacre-in-a-nairobi-mall/">Witness to a Massacre in a Nairobi Mall »</a></li>
<li><a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/04/tyler-hicks-a-decade-in-afghanistan/">Tyler Hicks: A Decade in Afghanistan »</a></li>
<li><a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/20/on-assignment-with-tyler-hicks-in-afghanistan/">On Assignment: Moments Between Life and Death »</a></li>
<li><a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/26/a-responsibility-to-photograph-and-remember/">A Responsibility to Photograph, and Remember »</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Hicks was part of a Times team that won the 2009 Pulitzer for international reporting from Afghanistan and Pakistan. He has won numerous international awards, including Newspaper Photographer of the Year from Pictures of the Year International in 2006.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“Though Tyler has never won an individual Pulitzer before, in my mind he’s won it every year,” Ms. McNally said. “This is the culmination of all the work he’s ever done for this paper. It is well deserved.”</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Hicks said, “It’s a huge honor to be recognized in this way, and it’s a reminder to me that these stories, however far away and however remote, are being noticed and that the risks that photographers all over the world take in going to dangerous places are being acknowledged and rewarded.”</p>
<div class="w480"><figure class="media photo promo" itemprop="" itemscope="" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000-blog480.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" role="group"><span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span><div class="image"><img itemprop="url" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000-blog480.jpg" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000-blog480.jpg" id="100000002825113" width="480" height="320" alt="Tyler Hicks, left, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography, and Josh Haner, right, winner for feature photography, with Michele McNally, assistant managing editor for photography, during the 2014 Pulitzer Prize announcements." class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000/20140414-lens-tka-slide-B000-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Tyler Hicks, left, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography, and Josh Haner, right, winner for feature photography, with Michele McNally, assistant managing editor for photography, during the 2014 Pulitzer Prize announcements." data-mediaviewer-credit="Richard Perry/The New York Times" /><meta itemprop="height" content="320"><meta itemprop="width" content="480"></div><figcaption class="caption" itemprop="description"><span class="caption-text">Tyler Hicks, left, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography, and Josh Haner, right, winner for feature photography, with Michele McNally, assistant managing editor for photography, during the 2014 Pulitzer Prize announcements.</span><span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"><span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span> Richard Perry/The New York Times</span></figcaption></figure></div>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Hicks was born in Brazil and raised in Westport, Conn. He worked at The Troy Daily News in Ohio, where he was hired by <a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/20/parting-glance-chris-hondros/">Chris Hondros</a>, who died in April 2011 while photographing in Libya. Mr. Hicks, 44, also worked at The Wilmington Morning Star in North Carolina.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">He lives in Nairobi and was just blocks from the mall when the attack started. As it unfolded, he went inside with security forces as they searched for the attackers. In an <a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/09/21/witness-to-a-massacre-in-a-nairobi-mall/">interview with Lens</a> later that day Mr. Hicks — who has covered the Afghanistan and Iraq wars and was among four Times journalists abducted and brutalized in Libya in 2011 — described the scene.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“I could see that there were multiple bodies lying dead in the mall, some lying together just next to where they were having lunch at a cafe,&#8221; he said. &#8220;It seemed everywhere you turned there was another body.”</p>
<div class="w165 right module">
<div class="entry">
<h6 class="kicker">Showcase</h6>
<h5>Josh Haner</h5>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2014/04/10/us/BEYOND.html"><img class="w165" alt="DESCRIPTION" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-DDER/20140414-lens-tka-slide-DDER-custom2.jpg" /></a></p>
<p class="summary">A look back at Mr. Haner&#8217;s work on Lens.</p>
<ul class="refer">
<li><a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/03/on-the-campain-trail-in-iowa/">On the Campaign Trail in Iowa»</a></li>
<li><a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/19/longshot/">Finding a Long Shot in Mexico</a>»</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">He said that an attack like the one in Nairobi was at least as dangerous, if not more so, than covering the Afghan war and that inside the mall he had to think about where he was standing, what to cover and the type of obstacles to place between him and the gunmen.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“This is just plain and simple murder of unarmed civilians,” said Mr. Hicks, who has covered many violent conflicts in his career, including Kosovo, Iraq, Afghanistan, Somalia and Sudan. “It’s not a war. These militants went into the mall and executed people: women and children, anyone who got in their path. That’s not typical of war.”</p>
<div class="w480"><figure class="media photo promo" itemprop="" itemscope="" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9-blog480.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" role="group"><span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span><div class="image"><img itemprop="url" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9-blog480.jpg" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9-blog480.jpg" id="100000002825147" width="480" height="295" alt="Tyler Hicks was applauded by colleagues and family during the announcement of the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes." class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9/20140414-lens-tka-slide-V7U9-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Tyler Hicks was applauded by colleagues and family during the announcement of the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes." data-mediaviewer-credit="Ruth Fremson/The New York Times" /><meta itemprop="height" content="295"><meta itemprop="width" content="480"></div><figcaption class="caption" itemprop="description"><span class="caption-text">Tyler Hicks was applauded by colleagues and family during the announcement of the 2014 Pulitzer Prizes.</span><span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"><span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span> Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></figcaption></figure></div>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Hicks passes the mall, now bullet ridden and boarded up, almost every day. Each time, he says, it brings back memories of the attack. Events like this attract global attention for a short while and then are often forgotten by most people, he said.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">He chooses to remember as much as he can.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“I don’t believe that it’s better to forget, after you volunteer to go and cover conflict or enter the Westgate Mall during a terrorist attack — you’re committing to that experience,” he said. “I think it would be disrespectful to the people you’ve photographed suffering in terrible circumstances to tuck those memories away and ignore them. You owe it to each person to not forget what happened. Once you have witnessed these events then they are part of you, they are a part of who you are.”</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Haner, 34, won the feature Pulitzer for his photographs of Jeff Bauman, who lost both legs in the Boston Marathon bombing. Mr. Haner followed Mr. Bauman, 28, over the course of two and a half months, documenting his struggles and private moments with his family and girlfriend.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Bauman was at the marathon to cheer on his girlfriend, Erin Hurley, when the bombs went off. A graphic photo of him being pushed in a wheelchair chair moments after the explosions, taken by Charles Krupa of The Associated Press, became one of the most widely published images from that day.</p>
<div class="w480"><figure class="media photo promo" itemprop="" itemscope="" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI-blog480.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" role="group"><span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span><div class="image"><img itemprop="url" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI-blog480.jpg" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI-blog480.jpg" id="100000002825227" width="480" height="307" alt="Jeff Bauman being wheeled away after the bombing in Boston." class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI/20140414-lens-tka-slide-XNLI-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Jeff Bauman being wheeled away after the bombing in Boston." data-mediaviewer-credit="Charles Krupa/Associated Press" /><meta itemprop="height" content="307"><meta itemprop="width" content="480"></div><figcaption class="caption" itemprop="description"><span class="caption-text">Jeff Bauman being wheeled away after the bombing in Boston.</span><span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"><span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span> Charles Krupa/Associated Press</span></figcaption></figure></div>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Haner arrived in Boston that evening to cover the aftermath, and over the next few days he worked with, among others, the reporter Tim Rohan, who had recently finished an internship at The Times.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Rohan, 24, connected with the Bauman family and wrote “<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/08/sports/beyond-the-finish-line.html?_r=0">Beyond the Finish Line</a>,” which detailed Mr. Bauman’s recovery. Together the journalists spent a lot of time with Mr. Bauman, at times playing video games with him when he was without other visitors.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">In an interview with the Nieman Storyboard site last year, Mr. Rohan described what happened when Mr. Haner started photographing the story.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“After the first week and a half our photographer, Josh Haner, joined in, and he fit like a glove,&#8221; Mr. Rohan said. &#8220;Everyone loves Josh, so when he came in he made the atmosphere lighthearted. It was a good mix of people. That really was important, to keep Jeff at ease.”</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Witnessing Mr. Baumann’s painful recovery was difficult for Mr. Haner.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“The most important thing I learned was when to not take a picture — knowing that there were certain moments to be respected and just let the moment stand on its own without the interruption of a click,” he said. “It’s knowing when a picture is exploitative and when it’s necessary for the story.”</p>
<div class="w480"><figure class="media photo promo" itemprop="" itemscope="" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF-blog480.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" role="group"><span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span><div class="image"><img itemprop="url" itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF-blog480.jpg" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF-blog480.jpg" id="100000002825132" width="480" height="367" alt="Josh Haner, right, hugged Jason Stallman, the sports editor, in the Times newsroom, where employees gathered for the announcement of the winners of the Pulitzer Prize." class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2014/04/14/blogs/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF/20140414-lens-tka-slide-8ESF-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Josh Haner, right, hugged Jason Stallman, the sports editor, in the Times newsroom, where employees gathered for the announcement of the winners of the Pulitzer Prize." data-mediaviewer-credit="Ruth Fremson/The New York Times" /><meta itemprop="height" content="367"><meta itemprop="width" content="480"></div><figcaption class="caption" itemprop="description"><span class="caption-text">Josh Haner, right, hugged Jason Stallman, the sports editor, in the Times newsroom, where employees gathered for the announcement of the winners of the Pulitzer Prize.</span><span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"><span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span> Ruth Fremson/The New York Times</span></figcaption></figure></div>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Haner also shot video daily, often carrying four DSLR’s — two equipped specifically for video and the other two for stills. A video produced by Mr. Haner, Catherine Spangler and Mr. Rohan won a first-place award in the Best of Photojournalism contest and a second place in Picture of the Year International for feature multimedia story.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Like Mr. Hicks, Mr. Haner also spoke about the length of the public’s memories.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“My concern is that people forget tragedies like this,” he said. “It’s important to bring attention to what survivors are going through and how their lives change, and help them.”</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Ms. McNally brought Mr. Haner to The Times in 2004 after he had worked for her at Fortune magazine for a year. He was a co-founder of the Lens blog in 2009. He is currently a staff photographer and the senior editor for photo technology.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Among his many contributions to the use and display of photos at The Times is developing a backpack-size transmission device that allows images from major events to be sent instantaneously and posted online within minutes. He has carefully guarded his technological advances from competitors.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Haner started photographing when he was 10 and immersed himself in photography at the free Harvey Milk Community Darkroom in San Francisco while in elementary school. In 1995, at the age of 15, he started interning with <a href="http://www.myamericaathome.com/customcover/mediainquiries">Against All Odds Productions</a>, run by the creator of the &#8220;Day in The Life&#8221; series of photo books, where he met Ms. McNally as well as the Times deputy photo editor Meaghan Looram.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">At Stanford University he studied symbolic systems, which combines computer science, philosophy, psychology and linguistics, and was also the photo editor for the school newspaper. After graduation, he moved into a trailer park for five months for a documentary <a href="http://www.joshhaner.com/albums/trailer-park/">photo project</a>, then went to work with Ms. McNally at Fortune.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“I hired Josh when he was 23, and at The Times I reconfigured his job from photo editor to technology editor to staff photographer,” she said. “He is brilliant and can do anything.”</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Like playing third base in a mostly Dominican baseball league. He played a doubleheader on Saturday in the Bronx with his team, the Downtown Bulls.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Haner submitted the project for the feature photography Pulitzer. He said that he understood that deciding what to submit was a difficult decision for The Times, particularly with so much good work done at the paper this year. At first he was not thinking of entering himself, but friends pushed him to do so.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">“I felt so passionately about this story and I felt that it was the best work I’d ever done and I did not want to have regrets haunting me in the future,” he said.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Today, standing before his colleagues in the newsroom, he reached a spot he had dreamed of as a child in the Bay area.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">&#8220;It&#8217;s what I wanted my whole life since I picked up the camera and was reading all the credits in the San Francisco Chronicle and was trying to figure out who all these photgraphers were and hoping one day to be among them,&#8221; he said.</p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody">Today, he was.</p>
<hr />
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody"><em>The complete slide show for both <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2014/04/10/us/BEYOND.html">Mr. Haner</a> and <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2014/04/10/world/africa/WESTGATE.html#1">Mr. Hicks</a>’s winning entries have been published on The New York Times.</em></p>
<p class="story-body-text" itemprop="articleBody"><em>Follow @<a href="https://twitter.com/joshhaner">joshhaner</a>, @<a href="https://twitter.com/TylerHicksPhoto">TylerHicksPhoto</a>, @<a href="https://twitter.com/JamesEstrin">JamesEstrin</a> and @<a href="http://www.twitter.com/nytimesphoto">nytimesphoto</a> on Twitter. Lens is also on <a href="http://www.facebook.com/nytimesphoto">Facebook</a>.</em></p>
        <div class="story theme-main">
                </div>
        	</div>
	</article>				</div><!-- end content -->
				<button class="button comments-button theme-speech-bubble"></button>		<div class="next-in-lens">
			<div class="next-in-lens-title">Next in Lens:</div>
						<h3 class="entry-title">
				<a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/14/last-night-to-bend-the-rules/" rel="bookmark"
				   title="Permanent Link to Last Night to Bend the Rules">
					Last Night to Bend the Rules				</a>
			</h3>
					</div>
	</div><!-- end .a-column -->
		<script>(function() {
	var getHeight = function( element, include ) {
		if ( ! include ) {
			include = {
				padding: false,
				border: false,
				margin: false
			};
		}

		var height = element.clientHeight;
		if ( ! include.padding ) {
			height -= parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( element, null )
			                .getPropertyValue( 'padding-top' ) ) +
			          parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( element, null )
			                .getPropertyValue( 'padding-bottom' ) );
		}
		if ( include.border ) {
			height += parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( element, null )
			                .getPropertyValue( 'border-top-width' ) ) +
			          parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( element, null )
			                .getPropertyValue( 'border-bottom-width' ) );
		}
		if ( include.margin ) {
			height += parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( element, null )
			                .getPropertyValue( 'margin-top' ) ) +
			          parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( element, null )
			                .getPropertyValue( 'margin-bottom' ) );
		}
		return height;
	};
	var setSinglePromoLayout = function() {
		var promoImg = document.querySelector('.lede-content .promo img'),
			potentialHeight = 0,
			imageAspectRatio = 0,
			promoImgMetaHeight = document.querySelector('.lede-content [itemprop="height"]'),
			promoImgMetaWidth = document.querySelector('.lede-content [itemprop="width"]');

		// If the proportions are in meta fields, use that to calculate aspect ratio.
		if ( promoImgMetaHeight && promoImgMetaWidth ) {
			var height = promoImgMetaHeight.getAttribute( 'content' ),
				width = promoImgMetaWidth.getAttribute( 'content' );
			imageAspectRatio = width / height;
		// Otherwise, load the image and get the actual dimensions.
		} else {
			imageAspectRatio = promoImg.width / promoImg.height;
			if ( ! imageAspectRatio ) {
				tempImage = new Image();
				tempImage.src = promoImg.getAttribute( 'src' );
				tempImage.addEventListener( 'load', function() {
					tempImage.parentNode.removeChild(tempImage);
					setSinglePromoLayout();
				});
				document.body.appendChild( tempImage );
				return;
			}
		}

		// The promo image should attempt to be rendered in no-crop layout.
		potentialHeight = getHeight( document.querySelector('.masthead'), { padding: true, border: true, margin: true } )
		                + getHeight( document.querySelector('.lens-masthead-container'), { padding: true, border: true, margin: true } )
		                + document.querySelector('.main > .generic-wrap').offsetWidth / imageAspectRatio;
		if ( window.innerHeight - potentialHeight < 100 ) {
			document.body.className = document.body.className.replace( 'theme-lede-in-a-column', '' );
			document.body.className = document.body.className.replace( 'theme-lede-full-width', '' );
			document.body.className = document.body.className + ' theme-lede-in-a-column';
			var potentialHeightWithImageFullWidth = getHeight( document.querySelector('.masthead'), { padding: true, border: true, margin: true } )
			                                      + getHeight( document.querySelector('.lens-masthead-container'), { padding: true, border: true, margin: true } )
			                                      + document.querySelector('.a-column').offsetWidth / imageAspectRatio;
			if ( window.innerHeight - potentialHeightWithImageFullWidth < 100 ) {
				document.body.className = document.body.className.replace( 'theme-lede-short', '' );
				document.body.className = document.body.className + ' theme-lede-short';
			} else {
				document.body.className = document.body.className.replace( 'theme-lede-short', '' );
			}

		} else {
			document.body.className = document.body.className.replace( /(?:^|\s)theme-lede-in-a-column(?!\S)/g , '' ) + ' theme-lede-full-width';
		}
	};

	if ( document.body.className.indexOf( 'single' ) != -1 ) {
		window.addEventListener( 'resize', setSinglePromoLayout );
		setSinglePromoLayout();
	}
})();</script>
	</div>
<div class="generic-wrap after-main">
	<div class="module featured-posts nocontent"><h4 class="section-heading">Featured Posts</h4></h4><article class="entry hentry post-143215 post type-post status-publish category-showcase tag-affordable-housing tag-photography tag-public-and-subsidized-housing tag-schalliol-david per-schalliol-david des-affordable-housing des-photography des-public-and-subsidized-housing news_keywords-photography" id="post-143215">
	<div class="w592"><figure class="media slideshow promo  " id="slideshow-100000004048415" data-media-action="link-to" aria-label="media" role="group"
		itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope
	itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/11/19/blogs/20151119-lens-housing-slide-S2XE/20151119-lens-housing-slide-S2XE-mediumThreeByTwo440.jpg"
	itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
	data-link-to="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/11/20/an-affordable-place-of-ones-own/"	>

<h4 class="entry-title"><a>Nov. 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day</a></h4>
</li>
	</ul>
	<h3 class="view-all-pictures-of-the-day">
		<a href="http://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/category/pictures-of-the-day/ ">
			View all Pictures of the Day
		</a>
	</h3>
	</div>
</div>

<script type="text/javascript">
var PREBID_TIMEOUT = 300;
var googletag = googletag || {};
googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error
    var mnSrc = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https:' : 'http:') + '//contextual.media.net/bidexchange.js?cid=8CU2553YN';
    document.write('<scr' + 'ipt type="text/javascript" src="' + mnSrc + '"></scr' + 'ipt>');
})();

    },

        '*': {
            'article/main': 'article/article/main'
        }
    }
};

    <a href="/upshot" class="section-heading upshot-nameplate-upshot"><h2>The Upshot</h2></a>

    <header id="story-header" class="story-header">
        
                <div id="story-meta" class="story-meta ">
                            <div class="ad sponsortile-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
                    <div class="caption">Supported by</div>
                    <div id="sponsortile" class="ad sponsortile-ad-creative"></div>

                                        <h3 class="kicker">
                                                                        Losing the Lead                </h3>
                        	<h1 itemprop="headline" id="story-heading" class="story-heading">The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest</h1>
                        <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">
                                                                    <p class="byline-dateline">
<time class="dateline" datetime="2014-04-22" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-04-22">APRIL 22, 2014</time>
</p>

                                                    <div class="inside-story">
                        <span class="menu-label">Inside</span>
                        <ul class="inside-story-menu"></ul>
                    </div>
                                                    <button class="button comments-button  theme-kicker" data-skip-to-para-id="">
</button>
                            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->
        </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </header>

                        <div class="extended-byline byline-dateline">

    <p class="byline">By                     <span itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/l/david_leonhardt/index.html">
                <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/l/david_leonhardt/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by DAVID LEONHARDT">                    <span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="David Leonhardt" itemprop="name">David Leonhardt and </span>
                </a>            </span>
                    <span itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/q/kevin_quealy/index.html">
                <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/q/kevin_quealy/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by KEVIN QUEALY">                    <span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="Kevin Quealy" itemprop="name">Kevin Quealy</span>
                </a>            </span>
            </p>
</div>
                            <div id="sharetools-story" aria-label="tools" role="group" class="sharetools theme-classic  sharetools-story  "
data-shares="email,facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet,save,show-all|more,ad"
data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/23/upshot/the-american-middle-class-is-no-longer-the-worlds-richest.html"
data-title="The American Middle Class Is No Longer the World’s Richest"
data-author="By DAVID LEONHARDT and KEVIN QUEALY"
data-media="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/04/22/upshot/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-usa-slide-1RJB/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-usa-slide-1RJB-jumbo.jpg"
data-description="After three decades of slow growth, middle-class incomes in the U.S. appear to trail those of Canada. Poor Americans now make less than the poor in several other countries."
	data-publish-date="April 22, 2014"
>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
<span class="sharetools-label visually-hidden">Share This Page</span>
<div class="ad sharetools-inline-article-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
<div id="MiddleLeft" class="ad middle-left-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent">
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
</div><!-- close shareTools -->
                    </div>


                
        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="90" data-total-count="90" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1">The American middle class, long the most affluent in the world, has lost that distinction.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="259" data-total-count="349" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">While the wealthiest Americans are outpacing many of their global peers, a New York Times analysis shows that across the lower- and middle-income tiers, citizens of other advanced countries have received considerably larger raises over the last three decades.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="186" data-total-count="535" itemprop="articleBody">After-tax middle-class incomes in Canada — substantially behind in 2000 — now appear to be higher than in the United States. The poor in much of Europe earn more than poor Americans.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="293" data-total-count="828" itemprop="articleBody">The <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/23/upshot/about-the-data.html">numbers, based on surveys</a> conducted over the past 35 years, offer some of the <a href="http://www.lisdatacenter.org/">most detailed publicly available comparisons</a> for different income groups in different countries over time. They suggest that most American families are paying a steep price for high and rising income inequality.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

                <header>
        <h2 class="module-heading">
                            Related Coverage
                    </h2>
    </header>

            <ul>
                                                            <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/23/upshot/about-the-data.html">

        
        <h2 class="story-heading">
                                                    <span class="story-heading-text">Losing the Lead: About the Data</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2014-04-22" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-04-22">APRIL 22, 2014</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
</article>
</li>
                                                                                <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/23/upshot/this-simple-table-summarizes-our-story-on-american-living-standards.html">

                    <div class="thumb">
                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2014/04/22/upshot/23upshot-lis-list-table-1398259218465/23upshot-lis-list-table-1398259218465-thumbStandard.png" alt="" />
                <div class="media-action-overlay"></div>
            </div>
        
        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">Losing the Lead: This simple table summarizes our story on American living standards.</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2014-04-22" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-04-22">APRIL 22, 2014</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
</article>
</li>
                                                                                <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/23/upshot/back-story-how-we-found-the-income-data.html">

        
        <h2 class="story-heading">
                                                    <span class="story-heading-text">Losing the Lead: Back Story: How We Found the Income Data</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2014-04-22" itemprop="datePublished" content="2014-04-22">APRIL 22, 2014</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
</article>
</li>
                                                </ul>
        </div><!-- close nocontent -->
    </aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="515" data-total-count="1343" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">Although economic growth in the United States continues to be as strong as in many other countries, or stronger, a small percentage of American households is fully benefiting from it. Median income in Canada pulled into a tie with median United States income in 2010 and has most likely surpassed it since then. Median incomes in Western European countries still trail those in the United States, but the gap in several — including Britain, the Netherlands and Sweden — is much smaller than it was a decade ago.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="145" data-total-count="1488" itemprop="articleBody">In European countries hit hardest by recent financial crises, such as Greece and Portugal, incomes have of course fallen sharply in recent years.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="265" data-total-count="1753" itemprop="articleBody">The income data were compiled by <a href="http://www.lisdatacenter.org/">LIS</a>, a group that maintains the Luxembourg Income Study Database. The numbers were analyzed by researchers at LIS and by The Upshot, a New York Times website covering policy and politics, and reviewed by outside academic economists.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="323" data-total-count="2076" itemprop="articleBody">The struggles of the poor in the United States are even starker than those of the middle class. A family at the 20th percentile of the income distribution in this country makes significantly less money than a similar family in Canada, Sweden, Norway, Finland or the Netherlands. Thirty-five years ago, the reverse was true.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="157" data-total-count="2233" itemprop="articleBody">LIS counts after-tax cash income from salaries, interest and stock dividends, among other sources, as well as direct government benefits such as tax credits.</p><figure id="23upshot-lis-inline-chart" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-sub-medium layout-xlarge">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <!-- 
 
======================================================

======================================================
 
-->

<!-- Pipeline: 40b019a9c4f3df3897af4fa81b4fbc117135e50c -->    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
                <div class="interactive-source">
            Source: New York Times/Luxembourg Income Study analysis        </div>
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="510" data-total-count="2743" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">The findings are striking because the most commonly cited economic statistics — such as <a href="http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD?order=wbapi_data_value_2012+wbapi_data_value+wbapi_data_value-last&sort=desc">per capita gross domestic product</a> — continue to show that the United States has maintained its lead as the world’s richest large country. But those numbers are averages, which do not capture the distribution of income. With a big share of recent income gains in this country flowing to a relatively small slice of high-earning households, most Americans are not keeping pace with their counterparts around the world.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="332" data-total-count="3075" itemprop="articleBody">“The idea that the median American has so much more income than the middle class in all other parts of the world is not true these days,” said <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/lkatz/biocv">Lawrence Katz</a>, a Harvard economist who is not associated with LIS. “In 1960, we were massively richer than anyone else. In 1980, we were richer. In the 1990s, we were still richer.”</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-5">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="49" data-total-count="3124" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-5">That is no longer the case, Professor Katz added.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="448" data-total-count="3572" itemprop="articleBody">Median per capita income was $18,700 in the United States in 2010 (which translates to about $75,000 for a family of four after taxes), up 20 percent since 1980 but virtually unchanged since 2000, after adjusting for inflation. The same measure, by comparison, rose about 20 percent in Britain between 2000 and 2010 and 14 percent in the Netherlands. Median income also rose 20 percent in Canada between 2000 and 2010, to the equivalent of $18,700.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="326" data-total-count="3898" itemprop="articleBody">The most recent year in the LIS analysis is 2010. But other income surveys, conducted by government agencies, suggest that since 2010 pay in Canada has risen faster than pay in the United States and is now most likely higher. Pay in several European countries has also risen faster since 2010 than it has in the United States.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-6">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="346" data-total-count="4244" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-6">Three broad factors appear to be driving much of the weak income performance in the United States. First, <a href="http://www.oecd.org/edu/eag2013%20%28eng%29--FINAL%2020%20June%202013.pdf">educational attainment</a> in the United States has risen far more slowly than in much of the industrialized world over the last three decades, making it harder for the American economy to maintain its share of highly skilled, well-paying jobs.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="521" data-total-count="4765" itemprop="articleBody">Americans between the ages of 55 and 65 have literacy, numeracy and technology skills that are above average relative to 55- to 65-year-olds in rest of the industrialized world, according to <a href="http://skills.oecd.org/OECD_Skills_Outlook_2013.pdf">a recent study</a> by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, an international group. Younger Americans, though, are not keeping pace: Those between 16 and 24 rank near the bottom among rich countries, well behind their counterparts in Canada, Australia, Japan and Scandinavia and close to those in Italy and Spain.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="319" data-total-count="5084" itemprop="articleBody">A second factor is that companies in the United States economy distribute a smaller share of their bounty to the middle class and poor than similar companies elsewhere. Top executives make substantially more money in the United States than in other wealthy countries. The minimum wage is lower. Labor unions are weaker.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="216" data-total-count="5300" itemprop="articleBody">And because the total bounty produced by the American economy has not been growing substantially faster here in recent decades than in Canada or Western Europe, most American workers are left receiving meager raises.</p><figure id="23upshot-middle-deciles-chart" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-small layout-xlarge">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-7">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            American Incomes Are Losing Their Edge, Except at the Top        </h2>
                <p class="interactive-leadin">
            Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit.        </p>
        </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <!--

<!-- Pipeline: 7a3447d4cec52420d9a5cdf7fde03b73888b2ef5 -->    </div>

<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="166" data-total-count="5466" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-7">Finally, governments in Canada and Western Europe take more aggressive steps to raise the take-home pay of low- and middle-income households by redistributing income.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="470" data-total-count="5936" itemprop="articleBody"><a href="http://www.gc.cuny.edu/Page-Elements/Academics-Research-Centers-Initiatives/Centers-and-Institutes/Luxembourg-Income-Study-Center/Janet-C-Gornick,-Director">Janet Gornick</a>, the director of LIS, noted that inequality in so-called market incomes — which does not count taxes or government benefits — “is high but not off the charts in the United States.” Yet the American rich pay lower taxes than the rich in many other places, and the United States does not redistribute as much income to the poor as other countries do. As a result, inequality in disposable income is sharply higher in the United States than elsewhere.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="211" data-total-count="6147" itemprop="articleBody">Whatever the causes, the stagnation of income has left many Americans <a href="http://www.pollingreport.com/right.htm">dissatisfied</a> with the state of the country. Only about 30 percent of people believe the country is headed in the right direction, polls show.</p><div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-8">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="279" data-total-count="6426" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-8">“Things are pretty flat,” said Kathy Washburn, 59, of Mount Vernon, Iowa, who earns $33,000 at an Ace Hardware store, where she has worked for 23 years. “You have mostly lower level and high and not a lot in between. People need to start in between to work their way up.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="503" data-total-count="6929" itemprop="articleBody">Middle-class families in other countries are obviously not without worries — some common around the world and some specific to their countries. In many parts of Europe, as in the United States, parents of young children wonder how they will pay for college, and many believe their parents enjoyed more rapidly rising living standards than they do. In Canada, people complain about the costs of modern life, from college to monthly phone and Internet bills. Unemployment is a concern almost everywhere.</p><div id="Moses" class="ad moses-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-9">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="144" data-total-count="7073" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-9">But both opinion surveys and interviews suggest that the public mood in Canada and Northern Europe is less sour than in the United States today.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-10">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="279" data-total-count="7352" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-10">“The crisis had no effect on our lives,” Jonas Frojelin, 37, a Swedish firefighter, said, referring to the global financial crisis that began in 2007. He lives with his wife, Malin, a nurse, in a seaside town a half-hour drive from Gothenburg, Sweden’s second-largest city.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="309" data-total-count="7661" itemprop="articleBody">They each have five weeks of vacation and comprehensive health benefits. They benefited from almost three years of paid leave, between them, after their children, now 3 and 6 years old, were born. Today, the children attend a subsidized child-care center that costs about 3 percent of the Frojelins’ income.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="324" data-total-count="7985" itemprop="articleBody">Even with a large welfare state in Sweden, per capita G.D.P. there has grown more quickly than in the United States over almost any extended recent period — a decade, 20 years, 30 years. Sharp increases in the number of college graduates in Sweden, allowing for the growth of high-skill jobs, has played an important role.</p><figure id="23upshot-canada-table" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-xsmall layout-xsmall">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-11">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">

    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="400" data-total-count="8385" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-11">Elsewhere in Europe, economic growth has been slower in the last few years than in the United States, as the Continent has struggled to escape the financial crisis. But incomes for most families in Sweden and several other Northern European countries have still outpaced those in the United States, where much of the fruits of recent economic growth have flowed into corporate profits or top incomes.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="111" data-total-count="8496" itemprop="articleBody">This pattern suggests that future data gathered by LIS are likely to show similar trends to those through 2010.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="186" data-total-count="8682" itemprop="articleBody">There does not appear to be any other publicly available data that allows for the comparisons that the LIS data makes possible. But two other sources lead to broadly similar conclusions.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="345" data-total-count="9027" itemprop="articleBody">A Gallup <a href="http://www.gallup.com/poll/166211/worldwide-median-household-income-000.aspx">survey</a> conducted between 2006 and 2012 showed the United States and Canada with nearly identical per capita median income (and Scandinavia with higher income). And <a href="http://topincomes.g-mond.parisschoolofeconomics.eu/">tax records</a> collected by Thomas Piketty and other economists suggest that the United States no longer has the highest average income among the bottom 90 percent of earners.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="238" data-total-count="9265" itemprop="articleBody">One large European country where income has stagnated over the past 15 years is Germany, according to the LIS data. Policy makers in Germany have taken a series of steps to hold down the cost of exports, including restraining wage growth.</p><div id="MiddleRight3" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-12">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-12">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="205" data-total-count="9470" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-12">Even in Germany, though, the poor have fared better than in the United States, where per capita income has declined between 2000 and 2010 at the 40th percentile, as well as at the 30th, 20th, 10th and 5th.</p><figure class="media slideshow in-page-player embedded has-adjacency layout-large-horizontal" data-media-action="inline" aria-label="media" role="group" data-url="" data-crop="">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-13">Continue reading the main story</a>
    <span class="visually-hidden">Slide Show</span>

HOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL-videoThumb.jpg"},"tmagSF":{"height":241,"width":362,"url":"http:\/\/static01.nyt.com\/images\/2014\/04\/22\/upshot\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL-tmagSF.jpg"},"filmstrip":{"height":190,"width":190,"url":"http:\/\/static01.nyt.com\/images\/2014\/04\/22\/upshot\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL-filmstrip.jpg"},"mediumThreeByTwo210":{"height":140,"width":210,"url":"http:\/\/static01.nyt.com\/images\/2014\/04\/22\/upshot\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL-mediumThreeByTwo210.jpg"},"master315":{"height":210,"width":315,"url":"http:\/\/static01.nyt.com\/images\/2014\/04\/22\/upshot\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL\/23UPSHOT-MIDDLE-Sweden-slide-WXBL-master315.jpg"}},"url":null,"short_url":null,"approved_for_syndication":false}]},"related_assets":[]}    </script>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="447" data-total-count="9917" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-13">More broadly, the poor in the United States have trailed their counterparts in at least a few other countries since the early 1980s. With slow income growth since then, the American poor now clearly trail the poor in several other rich countries. At the 20th percentile — where someone is making less than four-fifths of the population — income in both the Netherlands and Canada was 15 percent higher than income in the United States in 2010.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="406" data-total-count="10323" itemprop="articleBody">By contrast, Americans at the 95th percentile of the distribution — with $58,600 in after-tax per capita income, not including capital gains — still make 20 percent more than their counterparts in Canada, 26 percent more than those in Britain and 50 percent more than those in the Netherlands. For these well-off families, the United States still has easily the world’s most prosperous major economy.</p>
        
                                        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
                <div class="story-notes"><p>Rachel Z. Arndt contributed reporting from Mount Vernon, Iowa, and David Crouch from  Vallda, Sweden.</p>
<p>The Upshot provides news, analysis and data visualization about politics, policy and everyday life. Follow us on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/upshot">Facebook</a> and <a href="http://twitter.com/UpshotNYT">Twitter</a>.</p></div>
        
        
        <p class="story-print-citation">A version of this article appears in print on April 23, 2014, on page A1 of the <span itemprop="printEdition">New York edition</span> with the headline: U.S. Middle Class Is No Longer World’s Richest. <span class="story-footer-links">  <span><a href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?contentID=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2014%2F04%2F23%2Fupshot%2Fthe-american-middle-class-is-no-longer-the-worlds-richest.html&publisherName=The+New+York+Times&publication=nytimes.com&token=&orderBeanReset=true&postType=&wordCount=1714&title=The+American+Middle+Class+Is+No+Longer+the+World%E2%80%99s+Richest&publicationDate=April+22%2C+2014&author=By David Leonhardt and Kevin Quealy" target="_blank">Order Reprints</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span>  <span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/todayspaper/index.html" target="_blank">Today's Paper</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span><span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/subscriptions/Multiproduct/lp839RF.html?campaignId=48JQY" target="_blank">Subscribe</a></span>

           (function(){

        <div class="data-heading data-content channel-id-100000002500298">
          <h4 id="kicker">
              
              
                <a class="sub-kicker" href="/video/times-documentaries/">Times Documentaries</a>
              

          </h4>
          <h1 itemprop="name">The Making of Malala</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="data-content">
            <h5 id="byline"><span>By Gabe Johnson and Adam B. Ellick</span> <small> | Oct. 7, 2013</small>
              <span class="duration"><small> | 11:06</small></span>
            </h5>
            <p class="content-description" itemprop="description">The story of Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl, told by The Times’s Adam B. Ellick, who made a 2009 documentary about her before she was an international star.</p>
            <div class="content-related">
                
                    
                        
                            <strong class="related-title">Related: </strong>
                            <ul>
                        
                        
                                <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/08/world/asia/the-making-of-Malala.html"><strong><em class="article"></em> Article: </strong>Documenting a Pakistani Girl’s Transformation</a></li>
                        
                        
                            </ul>
                        
                    
                
            </div>
        </div>

        <script type="text/template" id="playlist-item-tmpl">
        
        
	
		
		{% for video in videos %}
	        {% set visible_state = 'hide' %}
	        {% set img_src_attr = 'src' %}
	        {% if sponsorPlaylist %}
			{% set video_url = video.seo_url|playlistOverride(video.playlist.id) %}
			{% else %}
			{% set video_url = video.seo_url|playlistOverride(playlist.id) %}
			{% endif %}
	  
  
	

	{% if video.playlist.type|getPlaylistType() === "show" %}
		{% set inChannel = false %}
		{% set inShow = true %}
	{% else %}
		{% if video.playlist.type|getPlaylistType() === "channel" %}
			{% set inChannel = true %}
			{% set inShow = false %}
		{% else %}
			{% set inChannel = false %}
			{% set inShow = false %}
		{% endif %}
	{% endif %}

	{% set itemPropURL = '' %}
	{% set itemPropContentURL = '' %}
	{% set itemPropName = '' %}
	{% set itemPropListElement = '' %}
	{% set itemScope = '' %}
	{% if pageType !== "watch" %}
		{% set itemPropURL = 'itemprop=url' %}
		{% set itemPropContentURL = 'itemprop=contentUrl' %}
		{% set itemPropName = 'itemprop=name' %}
		{% set itemPropListElement = 'itemprop=associatedMedia' %}
		{% set itemScope = 'itemscope itemtype=http://schema.org/ImageObject' %}
	{% endif %}

	<li data-id="{{ video.id }}"
		class="thumb-item {{ visible_state }} {% if !hideShowKicker %}show-enabled{% endif %} {{video.assetMeta.name}} {% if inShow %}channel-name-{{ video.playlist.parent_channel.headline | slugify | default('default') }} channel-id-{{ video.playlist.parent_channel.id }} {% else %} channel-name-default {% endif %} channel-themed" {{ itemPropListElement }} {{ itemScope }} >

		{% if !hideShowKicker %}
		<span class="show-logo">
			{% if inShow %}<a class="show-name-link" href="{{ video.playlist.publish_url|getPlaylistLabel() }}">{{ video.playlist.headline }}</a>{% else %}<span class="show-name-link">&nbsp;</span>{% endif %}
		</span>
		{% endif %}
		<a data-collection="{{playlist.headline}}" class="thumb-holder" href="{{ video_url }}" {{ itemPropURL }}>
			<span class="thumb-wrapper">
				<span class="thumb-border"></span>
				<span class="thumb-crop">
					<img class="thumb-img" alt="{{ video.headline }}" title="{{ video.headline }}" {{ img_src_attr }}="{{ 'images'|getDomain }}{{ video.images | getThumbImage(moduleType, pageType, default_images) }}" {{ itemPropContentURL }} />
				</span>
			</span>
			<div class="play-holder">
				<p class="button-play"><i class="times-sprite icon {{video.assetMeta.name}}"></i></p>
			</div>
		</a>
		{# To do using video metadata add link to the channel/section #}
		{% if !hideChannelKicker %}
		<h5 class="thumb-section-name">
			{% if inShow %}
				<a class="section-name-link" href="{{ video.playlist.parent_channel.publish_url|getPlaylistLabel() }}">{{ video.playlist.parent_channel.headline }}</a>
			{% else %}
				<a class="section-name-link" href="{{ video.playlist.publish_url|getPlaylistLabel() }}">{{ video.playlist.headline }}</a>
			{% endif %}

			{% if (video.duration > 0) %}
				<span class="duration">{{ video.duration | formatDuration }}</span>
			{% endif %}
		</h5>
		{% endif %}
		<a data-collection="{{playlist.headline}}" class="thumb-headline-holder" href="{{ video_url }}">
			<h3 class="thumb-headline" {{ itemPropName }}>{{ video.headline }}</h3>
		</a>
	</li>
	

	
		
			{% endfor %}
		
	


        
        </script>
        
        
    
    <script type="text/template" id="sharetools-video-tmpl">
        
    
    <div id="sharetools-video" class="sharetools"
    data-shares="email,embed,-,facebook,twitter,pinterest,showall|More"
    data-url="{{ video.domain }}{{ video.publish_url }}"
    data-tinyurl="{{ video.tiny_url }}"
    data-title="{{ video.headline }}"
    data-description="{{ video.summary }}"
    data-media="{{ 'images'|getDomain }}{{ video.images | getItem('type','videoLarge','url') | default('images/section/video/library/default-video-posterframe.png') }}"
    {% if not exclude["embed"] %}
        data-embed-code='<iframe title="New York Times Video - Embed Player" width="480" height="321" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="true" marginheight="0" marginwidth="0" id="nyt_video_player" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/video/players/offsite/index.html?videoId={{ video.id }}"></iframe>'
    {% endif %}
    data-assettype='{{ video.assetType }}'
    >
    </div>
    


    </script>
    <script type="text/template" id="video-meta-tmpl">
        
    
    {% set metaPrependTitle = "Video:" %}
    {% if playlist.isSponsor %}
        {% set metaPrependTitle = "Paid Post:" %}
    {% endif %}
    <meta name="medium" content="video">
    <meta property="og:url" content="{{ 'base'|getDomain }}{{ video.seo_url }}">
    <meta property="og:title" content="{{ metaPrependTitle }} {% if video.headline %}{{ video.headline }}{% else %}{{ defaultVideo.headline }}{% endif %}">
    <meta property="og:description" content="{{ video.summary }}">
    <meta property="og:type" content="article">
    <meta property="og:image" content="{{ 'images'|getDomain }}{{ video.images | getItem('type','videoSixteenByNine1050','url') | default('video/static-timesvideo/img/video-default-16by9-500x281.png') }}">
    <meta property="og:site_name" content="NYTimes.com - Video">
    <meta property="fb:app_id" content="9869919170"/>

    {% if (!playlist.isSponsor && video.rights && video.assetType < 2) %}
        <meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image">
        <meta name="twitter:image:src" content="{{ 'images-secure'|getDomain }}{{ video.images | getItem('type','videoSmall','url') | default('video/static-timesvideo/img/video-default-16by9-500x281.png') }}">
    {% else %}
        <meta name="twitter:card" content="summary">
        <meta name="twitter:image" content="{{ 'images-secure'|getDomain }}{{ video.images | getItem('type','videoSmall','url') | default('video/static-timesvideo/img/video-default-16by9-500x281.png') }}">
    {% endif %}

    <meta name="twitter:site" content="@nytimes">
    <meta name="twitter:url" content="{{ 'base'|getDomain }}{{ video.seo_url }}" />
    <meta name="twitter:title" content="{{ metaPrependTitle }} {% if video.headline %}{{ video.headline }}{% else %}{{ defaultVideo.headline }}{% endif %}" />
    <meta name="twitter:description" content="{{ video.summary | default(video.summary) }}" />
    


    </script>
    <script type="text/template" id="playlist-thumbs-tmpl">
        
    
    {% set margin = 5 %}
    <ul class="thumbs" role="tabpanel">
        {% include 'partials/watch/playlist-items.html' %}
    </ul>
    

    </script>
    <script type="text/template" id="playlist-items-tmpl">
      
  
      {% for videoItem in videos %}

      {% if videoItem.playlist.type|getPlaylistType() === "show" %}
        {% set inChannel = false %}
        {% set inShow = true %}
      {% else %}
        {% if videoItem.playlist.type|getPlaylistType() === "channel" %}
          {% set inChannel = true %}
          {% set inShow = false %}
        {% else %}
          {% set inChannel = false %}
          {% set inShow = false %}
        {% endif %}
      {% endif %}

      <li 
        id="thumb-{{ videoItem.id }}" 
        data-id="{{ videoItem.id }}" 
        data-index="{{ videoItem.index }}" 
        class="{{ nocontentFlag }} thumbContainer {{ ribbonItemStateClass }} {% if inShow %}channel-name-{{ videoItem.playlist.parent_channel.headline | slugify | default('default') }} channel-id-{{ videoItem.playlist.parent_channel.id }}  {% else %} channel-name-default {% endif %} channel-themed" 
        {% if itemWidth %} style="width: {{ itemWidth }}%"{% endif %}>

        {% if playlist.type|getPlaylistType() !== 'show' %}
          {% if (inShow) %}
          <a class="meta-link show-name" href="{{ videoItem.playlist.publish_url|getPlaylistLabel() }}"><h3>{% autoescape false %}{{ videoItem.playlist.headline|default('&nbsp;') }}{% endautoescape %}</h3></a>
          {% else %}
          <span class="meta-link show-name">&nbsp;</span>
          {% endif %}
        {% endif %}

        <a class='thumb' style="{% if margin %} margin-right: {{ margin }}% {% endif %}" href="{{videoItem.seo_url}}?playlistId={{ playlist.id }}" {{ isSponsor | attr("rel", "nofollow", '') }}>
          <span class="thumb-wrapper">
            <strong class="playing-label"><i class="icon"></i><span>Now Playing</span></strong>
            <span class="play-holder">
              <p class="play"><i class="icon {{videoItem.assetMeta.name}}"></i></p>
            </span>
            <span class="thumb-shade"></span>
            <span class="thumb-crop">
                <img id="img-{{ videoItem.id }}" src="{{ 'images'|getDomain }}{{ videoItem.images | getItemWithFallback('type',['videoSixteenByNine310', 'videoSmall', 'wide'],'url') | default(default_images.thumb_medium) }}" alt="{{ videoItem.headline }}" title="{{ videoItem.headline }}"/>
            </span>
          </span>
        </a>

        <h5 class="thumb-section-name">
          {% if inShow %}
            <a class="section-name-link" href="{{ videoItem.playlist.parent_channel.publish_url|getPlaylistLabel() }}">{% autoescape false %}{{ videoItem.playlist.parent_channel.headline }}{% endautoescape %}</a>
          {% else %}
            <a class="section-name-link" href="{{ videoItem.playlist.publish_url|getPlaylistLabel() }}">{% autoescape false %}{{ videoItem.playlist.headline }}{% endautoescape %}</a>
          {% endif %}

          {% if (videoItem.duration > 0) %}
            <span class="duration">{{ videoItem.duration | formatDuration }}</span>
          {% endif %}
        </h5>

        <a class='meta-link headline' href='{{videoItem.seo_url}}?playlistId={{ playlist.id }}'><h3>{{ videoItem.headline }}</h3></a>
      </li>
    {% endfor %}
  


    </script>

        </div> <!-- .app-container -->

            <script type="text/javascript">
                window.BackboneLocal = window.Backbone;
                var NYTD = NYTD || {};
                NYTD.env = "production";
                function getAppSettings(){
    var playlistType = "channel";
    var playlistHeadline = "Times Documentaries";
    var playlistDisplayName = "";
    var channelName = (playlistType === 'show' && playlistHeadline !== "") ? playlistDisplayName : playlistHeadline;

    var AppSettings = {
        domain: {
            base: "http://www.nytimes.com",
            js: "http://js.nyt.com/video/4.7.17-638_1447954390_2015-11-19T17:33:10Z/static-timesvideo",
            jsSecure: "https://sv.nyt.com/video/4.7.17-638_1447954390_2015-11-19T17:33:10Z/static-timesvideo",
            jsLegacy: "http://js.nyt.com",
            css: "http://css.nyt.com/video/4.7.17-638_1447954390_2015-11-19T17:33:10Z/static-timesvideo",
            cssLegacy: "http://css.nyt.com",
            images: "http://graphics8.nytimes.com/",
            imagesSecure: "https://sv.nyt.com/",
            imagesStatic: "http://graphics8.nytimes.com/video/4.7.17-638_1447954390_2015-11-19T17:33:10Z/static-timesvideo",
            html: "http://sv.nyt.com/video/4.7.17-638_1447954390_2015-11-19T17:33:10Z/static-timesvideo",
            htmlSecure: "https://sv.nyt.com/video/4.7.17-638_1447954390_2015-11-19T17:33:10Z/static-timesvideo",
            api: "http://www.nytimes.com",
            videoFactoryUrl: "",
            adxUrl: "https://www.nytimes.com/svc/adxmulti",
            adxRun: "https://www.nytimes.com/adx/bin",
            profileImage: "",
            searchNytimes: "http://query.nytimes.com/search/",
            searchVideo: "http://query.nytimes.com/search/video/",
            nyt5Host: "http://nytimes.com",
            nyt5MyAccount: "https://myaccount.nytimes.com",
            nyt5ProfileImage: "http://pimage.timespeople.nytimes.com",
            nyt5GatewayHost: "http://www.nytimes.com",
            gatewayPageName: "gateway_times_talk.nytimes.com",
            branded: "http://brandedplaylist.nytimes.com",
            readingListApi: "http://www.nytimes.com/svc/profile/reading-list/v1"
        },
        data: {
            env: "production",
            default_images: {
                "carousel": "video/static-timesvideo/img/video-default-15by7-1305x609.png",
                "thumb_small": "video/static-timesvideo/img/video-default-16by9-225x126.png",
                "thumb_medium": "video/static-timesvideo/img/video-default-16by9-310x174.png"
            },
            pageType: "watch",

    return AppSettings;

googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error
    var mnSrc = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https:' : 'http:') + '//contextual.media.net/bidexchange.js?cid=8CU2553YN';
    document.write('<scr' + 'ipt type="text/javascript" src="' + mnSrc + '"></scr' + 'ipt>');
})();
</script>

                                        <h3 class="kicker">
                        <span class="kicker-label"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/business/index.html">Business Day</a></span>                            <span class="pipe">|</span>                        Steven P. Jobs, 1955-2011                </h3>
                        	<h1 itemprop="headline" id="story-heading" class="story-heading">Apple’s Visionary Redefined Digital Age</h1>
                        <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">

data-title="Steve Jobs of Apple Dies at 56"
data-author="By JOHN MARKOFF"
data-media="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2011/10/06/blogs/06bits_blog/06bits_blog-jumbo.jpg"

        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="253" data-total-count="253" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/j/steven_p_jobs/index.html?inline=nyt-per" title="More articles about Steven P. Jobs." class="meta-per">Steven P. Jobs</a>, the visionary co-founder of <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/news/business/companies/apple_computer_inc/index.html?inline=nyt-org" title="More information about Apple Incorporated" class="meta-org">Apple</a> who helped usher in the era of personal computers and then led a cultural transformation in the way music, movies and mobile communications were experienced in the digital age, died Wednesday. He was 56.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="224" data-total-count="477" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">The death was announced by Apple, the company Mr. Jobs and his high school friend Stephen Wozniak started in 1976 in a suburban California garage. A friend of the family said the cause was complications of pancreatic cancer.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="235" data-total-count="712" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Jobs had waged a long and public struggle with the disease, remaining the face of the company even as he underwent treatment, introducing new products for a global market in his trademark blue jeans even as he grew gaunt and frail.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">For Apple, a Big Loss Requires a Balancing Act</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2011-10-05" itemprop="datePublished" content="2011-10-05">OCT. 5, 2011</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
