        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="204" data-total-count="204" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1">The women begin to arrive just before 8 a.m., every day and without fail, until there are thickets of young Asian and Hispanic women on nearly every street corner along the main roads of Flushing, Queens.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="344" data-total-count="548" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">As if on cue, cavalcades of battered Ford Econoline vans grumble to the curbs, and the women jump in. It is the start of another workday for legions of New York City’s manicurists, who are hurtled to nail salons across three states. They will not return until late at night, after working 10- to 12-hour shifts, hunched over fingers and toes.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="316" data-total-count="864" itemprop="articleBody">On a morning last May, Jing Ren, a 20-year-old who had recently arrived from China, stood among them for the first time, headed to a job at a salon in a Long Island strip mall. Her hair neat and glasses perpetually askew, she clutched her lunch and a packet of nail tools that manicurists must bring from job to job.</p><figure id="nails-series-box2" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency has-lede-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            Unvarnished        </h2>
                <p class="interactive-leadin">
            Articles in this series are examining the working conditions and potential health risks endured by nail salon workers.        </p>
        </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">

        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">3 Ways to Be a Socially Conscious Nail Salon Customer</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2015-05-07" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-05-07">MAY 7, 2015</time>

<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="358" data-total-count="1222" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">Tucked in her pocket was $100 in carefully folded bills for another expense: the fee the salon owner charges each new employee for her job. The deal was the same as it is for beginning manicurists in almost any salon in the New York area. She would work for no wages, subsisting on meager tips, until her boss decided she was skillful enough to merit a wage.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="81" data-total-count="1303" itemprop="articleBody">It would take nearly three months before her boss paid her. Thirty dollars a day.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="337" data-total-count="1640" itemprop="articleBody">Once an indulgence reserved for special occasions, manicures have become a grooming staple for women across the economic spectrum. There are now more than 17,000 nail salons in the United States, according to census data. The number of salons in New York City alone has more than tripled over a decade and a half to nearly 2,000 in 2012.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="522" data-total-count="2162" itemprop="articleBody">But largely overlooked is the rampant exploitation of those who toil in the industry. The New York Times interviewed more than 150 nail salon workers and owners, in four languages, and found that a vast majority of workers are paid below minimum wage; sometimes they are not even paid. Workers endure all manner of humiliation, including having their tips docked as punishment for minor transgressions, constant video monitoring by owners, even physical abuse. Employers are rarely punished for labor and other violations.</p><figure id="salons-graphic-1-english" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-small layout-sub-medium">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            The Manicure Capital        </h2>
                <p class="interactive-leadin">
            No American metropolitan area rivals New York for nail salons. Los Angeles and San Francisco, the closest, have about half as many salons per capita.        </p>
        </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <!--

======================================================

-->

			#g-salons1-artboard-300 .g-aiPstyle1 {
				font-size:10px;
				line-height:12px;
				font-weight:500;
				text-align:center;
				letter-spacing:0.10416666666667em;
				color:#000000;
			}
			#g-salons1-artboard-300 .g-aiPstyle2 {
				font-size:12px;
				line-height:14px;
				font-weight:500;
				text-align:center;
				color:#000000;
			}
			#g-salons1-artboard-300 .g-aiPstyle3 {
				font-size:12px;
				line-height:12px;
				font-weight:500;
				text-transform:uppercase;
				text-align:center;
				color:#000000;
			}
			#g-salons1-artboard-300 .g-aiPstyle4 {
				font-size:15px;
				line-height:10px;
				font-weight:700;
				text-align:center;
				color:#000000;

				color:#000000;

				font-size:12px;
				line-height:12px;

				color:#000000;
			}
		</style>

<script>require(['foundation/main'], function() { require(["http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/05/05/nail-salon-graphics/8c809ccf0964b0e732e359cd76d480a683c7063b/build.js"]); });</script><!-- Pipeline: 2015-05-05-nail-salon-graphics | May 7, 2015, 06:28PM | 8c809ccf0964b0e732e359cd76d480a683c7063b -->

            Source: ZIP Business Patterns, U.S. Census        </div>
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="367" data-total-count="2529" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">Asian-language newspapers are rife with classified ads listing manicurist jobs paying so little the daily wage can at first glance appear to be a typo. Ads in Chinese in both Sing Tao Daily and World Journal for NYC Nail Spa, a second-story salon on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, advertised a starting wage of $10 a day. The rate was confirmed by several workers.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="450" data-total-count="2979" itemprop="articleBody">Lawsuits filed in New York courts allege a long list of abuses: the salon in East Northport, N.Y., where workers said they were paid just $1.50 an hour during a 66-hour workweek; the Harlem salon that manicurists said charged them for drinking the water, yet on slow days paid them nothing at all; the minichain of Long Island salons whose workers said they were not only underpaid but also kicked as they sat on pedicure stools, and verbally abused.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="318" data-total-count="3297" itemprop="articleBody">Last year, the New York State Labor Department, in conjunction with several other agencies, conducted its first nail salon sweep ever — about a month after The Times sent officials there an inquiry regarding their enforcement record with the industry. Investigators inspected 29 salons and found 116 wage violations.</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-5">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="306" data-total-count="3603" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-5">Among the more than 100 workers interviewed by The Times, only about a quarter said they were paid an amount that was the equivalent of New York State’s minimum hourly wage. All but three workers, however, had wages withheld in other ways that would be considered illegal, such as never getting overtime.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="332" data-total-count="3935" itemprop="articleBody">The juxtapositions in nail salon workers’ lives can be jarring. Many spend their days holding hands with women of unimaginable affluence, at salons on Madison Avenue and in Greenwich, Conn. Away from the manicure tables they crash in flophouses packed with bunk beds, or in fetid apartments shared by as many as a dozen strangers.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="517" data-total-count="4452" itemprop="articleBody">Ms. Ren worked at Bee Nails, a chandelier-spangled salon in Hicksville, N.Y., where leather pedicure chairs are equipped with iPads on articulated arms so patrons can scroll the screens without smudging their manicures. They rarely spoke more than a few words to Ms. Ren, who, like most manicurists, wore a fake name chosen by a supervisor on a tag pinned to her chest. She was “Sherry.” She worked in silence, sloughing off calluses from customers’ feet or clipping dead skin from around their fingernail beds.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="311" data-total-count="4763" itemprop="articleBody">At night she returned to sleep jammed in a one-bedroom apartment in Flushing with her cousin, her cousin’s father and three strangers. Beds crowded the living room, each cordoned off by shower curtains hung from the ceiling. When lights flicked on in the kitchen, cockroaches skittered across the countertops.</p><figure id="media-100000003669424" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000003669424 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/07/nyregion/NAILSsub/NAILSsub-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/07/nyregion/NAILSsub/NAILSsub-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/07/nyregion/NAILSsub/NAILSsub-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Xue Sun, a manicurist who uses the name Michelle, in the Flushing, Queens, apartment she shared with her cousin, Jing Ren, and four other people. Curtains separate the beds." data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/07/nyregion/NAILSsub/NAILSsub-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="400" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Xue Sun, a manicurist who uses the name Michelle, in the Flushing, Queens, apartment she shared with her cousin, Jing Ren, and four other people. Curtains separate the beds.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="161" data-total-count="4924" itemprop="articleBody">Almost all of the workers interviewed by The Times, like Ms. Ren, had limited English; many are in the country illegally. The combination leaves them vulnerable.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="294" data-total-count="5218" itemprop="articleBody">Some workers suffer more acutely. Nail salons are governed by their own rituals and mores, a hidden world behind the glass exteriors and cute corner shops. In it, a rigid racial and ethnic caste system reigns in modern-day New York City, dictating not only pay but also how workers are treated.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="329" data-total-count="5547" itemprop="articleBody">Korean workers routinely earn twice as much as their peers, valued above others by the Korean owners who dominate the industry and who are often shockingly plain-spoken in their disparagement of workers of other backgrounds. Chinese workers occupy the next rung in the hierarchy; Hispanics and other non-Asians are at the bottom.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="287" data-total-count="5834" itemprop="articleBody">The typical cost of a manicure in the city helps explain the abysmal pay. A survey of more than 105 Manhattan salons by The Times found an average price of about $10.50. The countrywide average is almost double that, according to a <a title="The Nails Magazine survey (PDF)." href="http://files.nailsmag.com/Market-Research/NABB2014-2015-Stats-2-1.pdf">2014 survey by Nails Magazine</a>, an industry publication.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="56" data-total-count="5890" itemprop="articleBody">With fees so low, someone must inevitably pay the price.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="300" data-total-count="6190" itemprop="articleBody">“You can be assured, if you go to a place with rock-bottom prices, that chances are the workers’ wages are being stolen,” said Nicole Hallett, a lecturer at Yale Law School who has worked on wage theft cases in salons. “The costs are borne by the low-wage workers who are doing your nails.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="372" data-total-count="6562" itemprop="articleBody">In interviews, some owners readily acknowledged how little they paid their workers. Ms. Ren’s boss, Lian Sheng Sun, who goes by Howard, at first denied doing anything wrong, but then said it was just how business was done. “Salons have different ways of conducting their business,” he said. “We run our business our own way to keep our small business surviving.”</p><div id="Moses" class="ad moses-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><div class="ad mega-ad nocontent robots-nocontent">
        <div class="caption hidden">Advertisement</div><div id="MegaAd" class="mega-ad-creative"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div></div><div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="70" data-total-count="6632" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-6">Many owners said they were helping new immigrants by giving them jobs.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="423" data-total-count="7055" itemprop="articleBody">“I want to change the first generation coming here and getting disgraced, and getting humiliated,” said Roger Liu, 28, an immigrant from China, seated inside the salon he owned, Relaxing Town Nails and Spa in Huntington Station, N.Y. As he spoke last summer, an employee, a woman in her 50s, paced the salon, studying a scrap of paper scribbled with the steps of a pedicure, chanting them to herself quietly in Chinese.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="79" data-total-count="7134" itemprop="articleBody">It was her first week working in a salon, she said. Mr. Liu was not paying her.</p><figure id="media-100000003657262" class="media photo embedded layout-full-bleed-horizontal media-100000003657262 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb3/NAILSTEST13-superJumbo.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb3/NAILSTEST13-superJumbo.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb3/NAILSTEST13-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A worker gives a pedicure at Relaxing Town Nails and Spa in Huntington Station, N.Y." data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb3/NAILSTEST13-superJumbo.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="1367" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="2048" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A worker gives a pedicure at Relaxing Town Nails and Spa in Huntington Station, N.Y.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="585" data-total-count="7719" itemprop="articleBody">Compelled to work endless hours just to get by, the manicurists live lives that unspool almost entirely within the walls of their salons. An underground economy has sprung up in Flushing and other city neighborhoods where salon workers live, to help them cope. On weekdays, women walk from door to door like Pied Pipers, taking nail salon workers’ children to school for a fee. Many manicurists pay caregivers as much as half their wages to take their babies six days a week, 24 hours a day, after finding themselves unable to care for them at night and still wake up to paint nails.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="173" data-total-count="7892" itemprop="articleBody">Jing Ren usually spent days sleeping in her slim pallet a few feet from the bed of her 24-year-old cousin, Xue Sun, also a manicurist. She had no time to make other friends.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="130" data-total-count="8022" itemprop="articleBody">She eventually started taking English classes, hoping to grasp onto a new life, but she feared the gravitational pull of this one.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="105" data-total-count="8127" itemprop="articleBody">“I would feel petrified,” she said, “thinking that I’ll be doing this for the rest of my life.”</p><h4 id="subhead-1" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="19" data-total-count="8146" itemprop="articleBody">Low Prices, Low Pay</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="74" data-total-count="8220" itemprop="articleBody">As far as small businesses go, it is relatively easy to open a nail salon.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="307" data-total-count="8527" itemprop="articleBody">Just a few thousand dollars is needed for things like pedicure chairs with whirlpool baths. Little English is required, and there are few licensing hoops to jump through. Many skip them altogether. Overhead is minimal: rent and some new bottles of polish each month — and the rock-bottom wages of workers.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="176" data-total-count="8703" itemprop="articleBody">Beyond the low barriers for entry, manicurists, owners and others who have closely followed the nail industry are hard pressed to say definitively why salons have proliferated.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="213" data-total-count="8916" itemprop="articleBody">In the 1990s, nail polish brands began to market more directly to consumers, helping to fuel demand, according to Nails Magazine. Polishes also became more sophisticated; they last longer and are easier to remove.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-7">Continue reading the main story</a>

                <header>
        <h2 class="module-heading">
                            Related in <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/opinion/index.html">Opinion</a>
                    </h2>
    </header>

    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/12/opinion/justice-for-nail-salon-workers.html">

                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/12/opinion/12tue2web/12tue2web-thumbStandard.jpg" alt="Workers on Union Street in Flushing, Queens, waiting for vans to take them to nail salons." />
                <div class="media-action-overlay"></div>

        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">Editorial: Justice for Nail Salon Workers</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2015-05-11" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-05-11">MAY 11, 2015</time>
        </h2>

        </div><!-- close nocontent -->
    </aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="243" data-total-count="9159" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-7">Census data show the number of salons in New York surged through the 2000s, far outstripping the rest of the country. Growth dimmed slightly during the recession, as lacquered nails remained an affordable treat for many, before climbing again.</p><figure id="salons-graphic-3-english" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-8">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            Nail Salons Versus Starbucks        </h2>
                <p class="interactive-leadin">
            If you thought Starbucks was ubiquitous, here’s how it compares with nail salons in one Upper East Side neighborhood.        </p>
        </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">

<script>require(['foundation/main'], function() { require(["http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/05/05/nail-salon-graphics/8c809ccf0964b0e732e359cd76d480a683c7063b/build.js"]); });</script><!-- Pipeline: 2015-05-05-nail-salon-graphics | May 7, 2015, 06:28PM | 8c809ccf0964b0e732e359cd76d480a683c7063b -->
    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
                <div class="interactive-source">
            Source: Street by street survey; Jeanne Li        </div>
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="198" data-total-count="9357" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-8">But as nail salons have mushroomed, it has become harder to turn a profit, some owners said. Manicure prices have not budged much from 1990s levels, according to veteran workers. Neither have wages.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="256" data-total-count="9613" itemprop="articleBody">With their gleaming glass fronts, the salons seem to display their inner workings as transparently as a department store displays a holiday window. But much of how salons operate and how workers are treated is kept deliberately opaque to the outside world.</p><div id="MiddleRight3" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="227" data-total-count="9840" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-9">Among the hidden customs are how new manicurists get started. Most must hand over cash — usually $100 to $200, but sometimes much more — as a training fee. Weeks or months of work in a kind of unpaid apprenticeship follows.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="215" data-total-count="10055" itemprop="articleBody">Ms. Ren spent almost three months painting on pedicures and slathering feet with paraffin wax before one afternoon in the late summer when her boss drew her into a waxing room and told her she would finally be paid.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="159" data-total-count="10214" itemprop="articleBody">“I just burst into laughter unconsciously,” Ms. Ren said. “I have been working for so long while making zero money; now finally my hard work paid off.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="116" data-total-count="10330" itemprop="articleBody">That night her cousins threw her a party. The next payday she learned her day wage would amount to under $3 an hour.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="571" data-total-count="10901" itemprop="articleBody">Step into the prim confines of almost any salon and workers paid astonishingly low wages can be readily found. At May’s Nails Salon on 14th<sup></sup> Street in the West Village of Manhattan, where a photo of the singer Gwen Stefani with a manicurist hung on the wall, new employees must pay $100, then work unpaid for several weeks, before they are started at $30 or $40 a day, according to a worker. A man who identified himself as the owner, but would give his name only as Greg, said the salon did not charge employees for their jobs, but would not say how much they are paid.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="380" data-total-count="11281" itemprop="articleBody">At Sona Nails on First Avenue near Stuyvesant Town, a worker said she made $35 a day. Sona Grung, the owner of Sona Nails, denied paying below minimum wage, yet defended the practice, particularly of underpaying new workers. “When a beginner comes in, they don’t know anything, and they give you a job,” she said. “If you work in a nail salon for $35, it’s very good.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="693" data-total-count="11974" itemprop="articleBody">Nail salon workers are generally considered “tipped workers” under state and federal labor laws. Employers in New York are permitted to pay such workers slightly less than the state’s $8.75 minimum hourly wage, based on a complex calculation of how much a worker is making in tips. But interviews with scores of workers revealed rates of pay so low that the so-called tip calculation is virtually meaningless. None reported receiving supplemental pay from their bosses, as is legally required when their day’s tips fall short of the minimum wage. Overtime pay is almost unheard-of in the industry, even though workers routinely work up to 12 hours a day, six or even seven days a week.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="607" data-total-count="12581" itemprop="articleBody">Inside the hive of the salon, there are typically three ranks of workers. “Big Job” employees are veterans, experts at sculpting false nails out of acrylic dust. It is the most lucrative salon job, yet many younger manicurists avoid it because of the specter of serious health issues, including miscarriages and cancer, associated with inhaling fumes and clouds of plastic particles. “Medium Job” workers do regular manicures, while “Little Job” is the category of the beginners. They launder hot hand towels and sweep toenail clippings. They do work others do not want to do, such as pedicures.</p><figure id="media-100000003657604" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000003657604 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb5/NAILSTEST15-1430357381420-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb5/NAILSTEST15-1430357381420-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb5/NAILSTEST15-1430357381420-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="At Relaxing Town Nails and Spa in Huntington Station, N.Y., a customer has acrylic nails applied. One manicurist, standing, watches a more experienced woman do the job." data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb5/NAILSTEST15-1430357381420-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="400" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">At Relaxing Town Nails and Spa in Huntington Station, N.Y., a customer has acrylic nails applied. One manicurist, standing, watches a more experienced woman do the job.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="185" data-total-count="12766" itemprop="articleBody">More experienced workers usually earn $50 to $70 per day, sometimes even $80. Their pay, though, still typically amounts to significantly less than minimum wage, given their long hours.</p><div id="MiddleRight4" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-10">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="146" data-total-count="12912" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-10">In the poorer pockets of the city, at low-traffic salons in the Bronx and Queens, many workers are not paid a base wage at all, only a commission.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="502" data-total-count="13414" itemprop="articleBody">Nora Cacho was paid about 50 percent of the price of every manicure or lip wax she did at a Harlem shop that was part of a chain, Envy Nails. She frequently earned about $200 for each 66-hour workweek — about $3 an hour. In sandal season, if she was lucky, she left the shop with slightly more — $300 each week, she said. On snowy days, Ms. Cacho, who is part of a class-action lawsuit against the chain, would return home with nothing. The chain’s lawyer did not respond to requests for comment.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="182" data-total-count="13596" itemprop="articleBody">Ms. Cacho, who is from Ecuador, initially saw the industry as her financial salvation, as do many other immigrants. But what seems a way up usually gives way to a grinding existence.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="473" data-total-count="14069" itemprop="articleBody">Salon workers describe a culture of subservience that extends far beyond the pampering of customers. Tips or wages are often skimmed or never delivered, or deducted as punishment for things like spilled bottles of polish. At her Harlem salon, Ms. Cacho said she and her colleagues had to buy new clothes in whatever color the manager decided was fashionable that week. Cameras are regularly hidden in salons, piping live feeds directly to owners’ smartphones and tablets.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="366" data-total-count="14435" itemprop="articleBody">Qing Lin, 47, a manicurist who has worked on the Upper East Side for the last 10 years, still gets emotional when recounting the time a splash of nail polish remover marred a customer’s patent Prada sandals. When the woman demanded compensation, the $270 her boss pressed into the woman’s hand came out of the manicurist’s pay. Ms. Lin was asked not to return.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="44" data-total-count="14479" itemprop="articleBody">“I am worth less than a shoe,” she said.</p><h4 id="subhead-2" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="22" data-total-count="14501" itemprop="articleBody">An Ethnic Caste System</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="305" data-total-count="14806" itemprop="articleBody">As the throngs of manicurists gather in Flushing, Queens, every morning, the patter of “good mornings” is mostly in Chinese and Spanish, with the occasional snatches of Tibetan or Nepali. Korean is hardly ever heard among these workers heading to salons outside New York City, many of them hours away.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="137" data-total-count="14943" itemprop="articleBody">But to the customer settling into the comfort of a pedicure chair in Manhattan, it can seem as if nearly the entire work force is Korean.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="207" data-total-count="15150" itemprop="articleBody">The contrast stems from the stark ethnic hierarchy imposed by nail salon owners. Seventy percent to 80 percent of salons in the city are Korean-owned, according to the Korean American Nail Salon Association.</p><figure id="media-100000003656779" class="media photo embedded layout-full-bleed-horizontal media-100000003656779 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb6/NAILStest1-superJumbo.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb6/NAILStest1-superJumbo.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb6/NAILStest1-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A typical morning scene in Flushing, Queens: Salon workers are picked up by vans that will take them to work. Manicurists from Korea dominate in Manhattan; others are often shuttled to the other boroughs or out of the city, where business is slower.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;" data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb6/NAILStest1-superJumbo.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="1367" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="2048" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A typical morning scene in Flushing, Queens: Salon workers are picked up by vans that will take them to work. Manicurists from Korea dominate in Manhattan; others are often shuttled to the other boroughs or out of the city, where business is slower.<br /><br /></span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="406" data-total-count="15556" itemprop="articleBody">Korean manicurists, particularly if they are youthful and attractive, typically have their pick of the most desirable jobs in the industry — shiny shops on Madison Avenue and in other affluent parts of the city. Non-Korean manicurists are often forced into less desirable jobs in the boroughs outside Manhattan or even farther out from the city, where customers are typically fewer and tips often paltry.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="208" data-total-count="15764" itemprop="articleBody">In general, Korean workers earn at least 15 percent to 25 percent more than their counterparts, but the disparity can sometimes be much greater, according to manicurists, beauty school instructors and owners.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="200" data-total-count="15964" itemprop="articleBody">Some bosses deliberately prey on the desperation of Hispanic manicurists, who are often drowning under large debts owed to “coyotes” who smuggled them across the border, workers and advocates say.</p><div id="MiddleRight5" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-11">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="240" data-total-count="16204" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-11">Many Korean owners are frank about their prejudices. “Spanish employees” are not as smart as Koreans, or as sanitary, said Mal Sung Noh, 68, who is known as Mary, at the front desk of Rose Nails, a salon she owns on the Upper East Side.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="389" data-total-count="16593" itemprop="articleBody">Ms. Noh’s salon sits behind the construction barricades of the Second Avenue subway line. Perhaps as a result, she employs a handful of Hispanic women. (Less lucrative shops on out-of-the-way streets or on the second stories of buildings tend to be more diverse.) Ms. Noh said she kept her Hispanic manicurists at the lowest rung of work. “They don’t want to learn more,” she said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="291" data-total-count="16884" itemprop="articleBody">Ethnic discrimination imbues other aspects of salon life. Male pedicure customers are despised by many manicurists for their thick toenails and hair-covered knuckles. When a man comes into the store, almost invariably a non-Korean worker is first draft for his foot bath, salon workers said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="360" data-total-count="17244" itemprop="articleBody">Ana Luisa Camas, 32, an Ecuadorean immigrant, said that at a Korean-owned Connecticut salon where she worked, she and her Hispanic colleagues were made to sit in silence during their entire 12-hour shifts, while the Korean manicurists were free to chat. “For two years I suffered from headaches,” she said. “It was just the stress that was killing me.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="259" data-total-count="17503" itemprop="articleBody">Lhamo Dolma, 39, a manicurist from Tibet who goes by Jackey, recalled a former job at a Brooklyn salon where she had to eat lunch every day standing in a kitchenette with the shop’s other non-Korean workers, while her Korean counterparts ate at their desks.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-12">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="266" data-total-count="17769" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-12">“Their country people, they are completely free,” she said in an interview in her house in Queens, seated on a low settee beneath her household’s Buddhist shrine. She began to cry. “Why do they make us two different?” she said. “Everybody is the same.”</p><h4 id="subhead-3" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="17" data-total-count="17786" itemprop="articleBody">A Scared Newcomer</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="293" data-total-count="18079" itemprop="articleBody">There was a bright blue Siamese fighting fish in a Mason jar in a corner of the one-bedroom apartment where Ms. Ren lived with her cousin and four other adults. It rested on a table made from a broken cabinet door. Its name was July, after the month she was told she would finally earn a wage.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="172" data-total-count="18251" itemprop="articleBody">It was a rare moment of accomplishment for Ms. Ren, now 21, in her early days in New York City. She had holed up indoors for weeks after arriving, too scared to go outside.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="397" data-total-count="18648" itemprop="articleBody">She wished she could be like her older cousin and roommate, Ms. Sun, who emerged from their apartment in Flushing each morning looking more like her customers than a manicurist, in bargain-store imitations of Hermès and Chanel. Ms. Sun woke up early each morning to steam her outfit — even her denim shorts — so that all traces of their grim quarters stayed shut up behind the apartment door.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="325" data-total-count="18973" itemprop="articleBody">When business at the salon began to slow in late 2013, Ms. Sun, who goes by Michelle, had an idea. She hopped a cheap bus south to Florida, a place she knew little about other than that it was always warm. She figured sandals — and pedicures — were year-round staples. She wandered from shop to shop until she found work.</p><div id="MiddleRight6" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-13">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="233" data-total-count="19206" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-13">Upon her return in spring 2014, Ms. Sun was upset to find Ms. Ren nearly a shut-in. Ms. Sun cajoled her younger charge to call salons listing openings online, taking the phone from her when she was too scared to speak to shop owners.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="185" data-total-count="19391" itemprop="articleBody">The day after, Ms. Ren stood on the corner of Franklin Avenue and Kissena Boulevard, her lunchbox in hand, waiting for a van to deliver her to her new salon — where, she did not know.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="389" data-total-count="19780" itemprop="articleBody">At Bee Nails, the salon in Hicksville, Ms. Ren fumbled even the most simple tasks at first, overwhelmed by nerves. She spent her days making piles of paper twists to swaddle pedicured toes, or cleaning up nail clippings. Her hands trembled when she tried to paint even her own nails in the break room. She refused to join the other Little Job workers for practice sessions, watching shyly.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="181" data-total-count="19961" itemprop="articleBody">A week in, her first manicure was on a man. His girlfriend sat next to him, whispering to him about the manicurist’s shaking hands. Ms. Ren said later her hands only shook harder.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="206" data-total-count="20167" itemprop="articleBody">“I tried to calm down on my way back in the van — it’s a long trip and quiet,” she said. “I told myself that I have to prove that I’m capable of conquering all these difficulties and make it.”</p><figure id="media-100000003665335" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003665335 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/05/nyregion/10NAILSweb12/10NAILSweb12-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/05/nyregion/10NAILSweb12/10NAILSweb12-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/05/nyregion/10NAILSweb12/10NAILSweb12-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Jing Ren, left, paints the nails of her cousin, Xue Sun, in the apartment they once shared with several other people in Flushing, Queens." data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/05/nyregion/10NAILSweb12/10NAILSweb12-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Jing Ren, left, paints the nails of her cousin, Xue Sun, in the apartment they once shared with several other people in Flushing, Queens.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="346" data-total-count="20513" itemprop="articleBody">At home she stayed up late practicing manicures on her cousin and drafted careful ledgers of her expenses. Her sole income was a few dollars a day in tips, but she was meticulous, tabulating each banana and even her first ice cream from a chiming truck. Beside a doodle of a cone, she wrote “$1.50.” Next to it, in English: “It’s good!”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="627" data-total-count="21140" itemprop="articleBody">By October, Ms. Ren had mostly tamed her anxiety. One Sunday morning, as a visitor watched, she sat balanced froglike on a small stool as she hoisted up the feet of a woman in a pink Juicy Couture track suit, deftly scratching off calluses with a roughened foam brick. The woman scrolled on her phone and picked at her cuticles. She addressed Ms. Ren once, when she warned the manicurist of a blister on her heel. Every so often, Ms. Ren sent a nail polish bottle or cuticle nipper flying, but she covered up her error with a titter and useful English phrases her boss encouraged her to practice. “So sorry,” she whispered.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="435" data-total-count="21575" itemprop="articleBody">Some evenings, Ms. Sun’s father, a line cook in Manhattan, would whip up elaborate meals of soft-shelled turtle and taro for the young women that reminded them of home. At night, he tucked them into bed with words of encouragement, before drawing closed the wall of curtain that separated his bed from theirs. Try to think of customers’ feet as pig’s feet, he would urge. Don’t they love that Chinese delicacy when he makes it?</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="455" data-total-count="22030" itemprop="articleBody">As the cold set in, a time of year when many bosses fire much of their salon staff, Ms. Ren grew anxious again. On slow days, she was sent to stand beside the highway in front of the salon in her green uniform bib, waving fliers. A customer review on the salon’s Yelp page described it as “basically a sweatshop,” and she felt it. Sometimes, she spent entire days dusting hundreds of individual plastic boxes of customers’ personal nail tool kits.</p><div id="MiddleRight7" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-14">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="63" data-total-count="22093" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-14">“I felt what I had to do was so pointless,” she later said.</p><h4 id="subhead-4" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="19" data-total-count="22112" itemprop="articleBody">Behind the Mercedes</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="363" data-total-count="22475" itemprop="articleBody">A gold pendant embossed with Chinese characters and entwined with red thread hangs on the door of a two-story house in Center Moriches, on Long Island, about an hour’s drive east from where Ms. Ren works in Hicksville. A wide creek that empties into Moriches Bay lies on the other side of the street. A Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle parks in the driveway.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="258" data-total-count="22733" itemprop="articleBody">It is the home of the owner of Nail Love, a salon in a nearby shopping center. The charm on the door invokes financial prosperity for the house’s inhabitants. But the lives of the half-dozen manicurists who bunk in the basement are anything but prosperous.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="319" data-total-count="23052" itemprop="articleBody">They are employees of Nail Love. Their dimly lit warren is a barracks provided by the salon’s owner, a common arrangement for workers in salons outside commuting distance from New York City. It saves owners money and sometimes even turns a profit. In some other such situations, workers must pay rent to their bosses.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="542" data-total-count="23594" itemprop="articleBody">Nail salon owners are often the success stories of their immigrant communities. Some owners rose from the ranks of manicurists themselves. In interviews, many owners expressed a vision of themselves as heroic, shouldering the burden of training workers and the risk of employing people who are not legally permitted to work in the United States. Fees extracted from new workers like Ms. Ren are proper compensation for the inconvenience of providing training, they said. Several owners said they felt betrayed when their workers quit or sued.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-15">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="328" data-total-count="23922" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-15">“They don’t stop to think how difficult it is nowadays to keep the door of our business open to service people,” Romelia M. Agudo, the former owner of a Park Slope salon, Romy’s Nails, wrote in an affidavit asking a judge to dismiss a lawsuit by two of her employees who said they were underpaid and denied lunch breaks.</p><figure id="media-100000003656794" class="media photo embedded layout-full-bleed-horizontal media-100000003656794 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb9/10nailsweb9-superJumbo-v2.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb9/10nailsweb9-superJumbo-v2.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb9/10nailsweb9-superJumbo-v2.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Inside Iris Nails on Madison Avenue between 87th and 88th Streets. At the two Iris salons on Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side, longtime workers described starting out at wages of $30 and $40 a day." data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb9/10nailsweb9-superJumbo-v2.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="1368" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="2048" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Inside Iris Nails on Madison Avenue between 87th and 88th Streets. At the two Iris salons on Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side, longtime workers described starting out at wages of $30 and $40 a day.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="75" data-total-count="23997" itemprop="articleBody">Many owners defended their business methods as the only way to stay afloat.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="286" data-total-count="24283" itemprop="articleBody">Ansik Nam, former president of the Korean American Nail Salon Association, said that in the early 2000s, scores of owners held an emergency meeting at a Korean restaurant in Flushing, hoping to prevent manicure and pedicure prices from sagging further. He said no agreement was reached.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="219" data-total-count="24502" itemprop="articleBody">The association’s current president, Sangho Lee, declined a request to address issues of underpayment. So many owners do not pay minimum wage, he said, that he believed answering any questions would hurt the industry.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="389" data-total-count="24891" itemprop="articleBody">Tucked between the hand dryers of NYC Nail Spa on the Upper West Side, where the beginners’ wage is $10 a day, the grim math of the nail salon industry is seemingly laid bare on a neatly typed sign, urging customers in broken English to tip well: “Less tips make us hard to hire good workers, or we have to pay higher wages to hire them, which might also cause a raise on the price.”</p><figure id="salons-graphic-2-english" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-xsmall layout-xsmall">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-16">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            A Boom in Nail Salons        </h2>
                <p class="interactive-leadin">
            The salon industry in the New York area is growing faster than in any other area of the country.        </p>
        </figcaption>

<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="483" data-total-count="25374" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-16">In an interview, the owner’s wife, who would give only her first name, Hwu, said the salon’s sales exceeded $400,000 a year but there were significant expenses as well, like rent and payroll. Speaking at the salon in February, shortly after her husband dropped her off in their Cadillac S.U.V., she said some of her beginners were not paid $10 a day. She pointed to a male manicurist on his first day on the job: If he did not show promise, she said, he would not be paid at all.</p><div id="MiddleRight8" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-17">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="394" data-total-count="25768" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-17">The owners of Iris Nails, a chain with shops in Manhattan and Brooklyn, had seven stores that generated sales of $8 million per year, according to a 2012 article in Korea Daily, a Korean-American newspaper. At the two Iris salons on Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side, longtime workers described starting out at wages of $30 and $40 a day. The owners did not respond to requests for comment.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="65" data-total-count="25833" itemprop="articleBody">The contrast between owners’ and workers’ lives can be stark.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="563" data-total-count="26396" itemprop="articleBody">Sophia Hong, who owned Madison Nails in Scarsdale, N.Y., prides herself on her art collection, including at least one work by Park Soo Keun, a Korean artist who had a painting sell for nearly $2 million at Christie’s in 2012. The art hangs in her home in Bayside, Queens, one of several properties she owns, according to property records, including a Manhattan apartment in a luxury building overlooking Columbus Circle. In 2010, she was sued by an employee at her Scarsdale salon for failing to pay overtime. The case was settled. Ms. Hong declined to comment.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-18">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="422" data-total-count="26818" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-18">In rare instances when owners have been found guilty of wage theft, salons have often been quickly sold, sometimes to relatives. The original proprietors vanish, along with their assets, according to prosecutors. Even if they do not, collecting back wages is difficult. Owners can claim they do not have the means to pay, and it is often impossible to prove otherwise, given how unreliable salons’ financial records are.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="403" data-total-count="27221" itemprop="articleBody">Despite <a title="Article from The Times." href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/11/nyregion/new-york-nail-salon-workers-uniting-against-job-abuses.html">winning a landmark court award of over $474,000 in 2012 for underpayment</a>, six manicurists from a chain of Long Island salons under the name Babi have so far received less than a quarter of that, they said. The chain’s owner, In Bae Kim, said he did not have the money, even though records show he sold his house for $1.13 million and a commercial property for $2 million just before the trial.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="242" data-total-count="27463" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Kim was arrested last year by the state attorney general’s office on charges of harassing a manicurist at the worker’s new job. He pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct on Jan. 3 and was sentenced to time served — eight days in jail.</p><h4 id="subhead-5" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="22" data-total-count="27485" itemprop="articleBody">Lack of Investigations</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="348" data-total-count="27833" itemprop="articleBody">During the nearly three months Ms. Ren worked unpaid in the Long Island nail salon, like many manicurists, she had no idea that it was against the law, or that the $30 day wage her boss finally paid her was also illegally low. As an immigrant, she felt happy to have any work at all, she said, and scared to complain. Furthermore, who would listen?</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="486" data-total-count="28319" itemprop="articleBody">The Labor Department is the New York State agency responsible for monitoring wage violations. An examination by The Times of the department’s enforcement database dating from 2008, obtained under the state’s Freedom of Information Law, found the department typically opens two or three dozen nail salon cases a year across the entire state. According to census data, there were more than 3,600 nail salons in the state in 2012, the most recent year for which figures were available.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="151" data-total-count="28470" itemprop="articleBody">The department opened a vast majority of these cases in response to worker complaints, as opposed to initiating its own investigations, the data shows.</p><div id="MiddleRight9" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-19">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="572" data-total-count="29042" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-19">A team of investigators regularly performs undercover sweeps of businesses suspected of breaking the law, but the agency had never conducted a sweep of nail salons until last year, said Christopher White, a spokesman for the Labor Department. He declined last month to say more about the salons in the operation or the violations found, because the investigation had not yet been closed. But a review of the 37 cases opened in 2014 showed that almost one-third of them involved shops from a single chain, Envy Nails, the one facing a class-action lawsuit from its workers.</p><figure id="media-100000003657276" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency layout-large-horizontal media-100000003657276 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb10/NAILStest14-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb10/NAILStest14-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb10/NAILStest14-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A customer chooses a good match to touch up her nails. Walking in the door, customers are often greeted with, &quot;Pick a color.&quot;" data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb10/NAILStest14-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="400" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A customer chooses a good match to touch up her nails. Walking in the door, customers are often greeted with, "Pick a color."</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="196" data-total-count="29238" itemprop="articleBody">When the department does investigate a salon, more than 80 percent of the time the agency finds workers have been unpaid or underpaid and tries to recover the money, The Times’s analysis showed.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="220" data-total-count="29458" itemprop="articleBody">The department declined to make anyone available to discuss its investigative work on the record. It took nine months of repeated inquiries from The Times for the department to turn over part of its enforcement database.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="144" data-total-count="29602" itemprop="articleBody">Only a small number of the workers interviewed by The Times said they had ever seen an investigator, from any government agency, at their salon.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="372" data-total-count="29974" itemprop="articleBody">Among the Labor Department’s 115 investigators statewide — 56 are based in New York City — 18 speak Spanish and 8 speak Chinese, essential tools for questioning immigrant workers to uncover whether they are being exploited. But just two speak Korean, according to the department. Department officials say all of their inspectors have access to interpreting services.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="501" data-total-count="30475" itemprop="articleBody">When investigators try to interview them, manicurists are frequently reluctant to cooperate, more so than in any other industry, according to a Labor Department official involved who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the official was not permitted to talk with reporters. “It’s really the only industry we see that in,” the person said, explaining that it most likely indicated just how widespread exploitation is in nail salons. “They are totally running scared in this industry.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="308" data-total-count="30783" itemprop="articleBody">Manicurists are also required to be licensed, but this is another area where enforcement is lax. There are nearly 30,000 licensed nail technicians in the state, according to the New York Department of State, but numerous manicurists work without licenses. Licenses are frequently fabricated, bought and sold.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="96" data-total-count="30879" itemprop="articleBody">Manicurists say that even when government agencies do check on their employers, evasion is easy.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="305" data-total-count="31184" itemprop="articleBody">Lili, a manicurist from Ecuador who is picked up every morning in Flushing near Ms. Ren, laughs when she recalls the time state inspectors visited the Westchester County salon where she works. Spotting them, her boss barked for all the unlicensed workers — there were 10 — to hustle out the back door.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="284" data-total-count="31468" itemprop="articleBody">“So we left, we got in the car, and we took a spin around the neighborhood,” said Lili, who declined to give her surname because she is in this country illegally. “Twenty, 30 minutes later we returned. After they’d gone. We put our uniforms back on and we returned to work.”</p><h4 id="subhead-6" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="10" data-total-count="31478" itemprop="articleBody">No Refunds</h4><div id="MiddleRight10" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-20">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-20">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="486" data-total-count="31964" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-20">This past fall, Ms. Ren’s parents arrived from China. Work had dried up for her mother, an insurance saleswoman, and father, a sometime chef, and they missed their only child. The visitors stuffed the one-bedroom with a total of eight bodies before Ms. Ren, her mother and her father had to move out. The manicurist packed up her pet fish, and the family installed itself a few blocks down Union Street in a dank basement apartment, where for $830 a month the three share one bedroom.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="76" data-total-count="32040" itemprop="articleBody">At work Ms. Ren earned a raise, lifting her spirits. She now made $40 a day.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="316" data-total-count="32356" itemprop="articleBody">Inspired by her cousin, who had enrolled again in English classes, Ms. Ren signed up as well in October, three days a week. School, she hoped, would be a way out of a job she had come to loathe, but some days her hands ached too much to go to class — she could not hold a pencil. Other days she was just too tired.</p><figure id="media-100000003656781" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003656781 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb11/nailstest2-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb11/nailstest2-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb11/nailstest2-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Jing Ren, 21,&amp;nbsp; on a rare day off from school and work, doing errands around her Queens neighborhood. Some days, her hands ache too much for her to go to class." data-mediaviewer-credit="Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/04/30/nyregion/10nailsweb11/nailstest2-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Jing Ren, 21,&nbsp; on a rare day off from school and work, doing errands around her Queens neighborhood. Some days, her hands ache too much for her to go to class.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Nicole Bengiveno/The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="511" data-total-count="32867" itemprop="articleBody">Around the time her first semester of English classes wrapped up, Ms. Ren asked for another raise. It was then she learned there are actually two price lists at her salon. One is for customers. The other is jotted down in a hidden-away notebook and lists the prices employees must pay the owner to learn new skills: such as $100 for eyebrow waxing, $100 to learn how to apply gel and cure it with ultraviolet light. A raise would require a new skill — her boss suggested eyebrows and gel — and the cash fee.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="332" data-total-count="33199" itemprop="articleBody">She was in the nail salon van when her boss told her of the fee, as he drove her to a different Long Island salon he owns. He shuttles employees between the two shops, depending upon which is busiest. An iPad propped on the dashboard played video feeds from both salons. Ms. Ren responded to the new fee with uncharacteristic furor.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="72" data-total-count="33271" itemprop="articleBody">Her boss relented: He would give her a 50 percent discount. She refused.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="159" data-total-count="33430" itemprop="articleBody">“I already paid when I first came,” she said. “Now I’m an employee and have been here for so long. Why do I still have to pay to pick up new skills?”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="230" data-total-count="33660" itemprop="articleBody">In an interview, Mr. Sun, Ms. Ren’s boss, said the fees were “deposits” so employees did not leave with their new skills for another salon, and were eventually refunded. Ms. Ren said she never got back the $100 she had paid.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="199" data-total-count="33859" itemprop="articleBody">For weeks after the van ride, she dreamed of quitting. But there was another semester of English classes in the spring, and though her parents pledged to help support her, they could not do it alone.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="232" data-total-count="34091" itemprop="articleBody">The final affront was a red envelope embossed in gold, a traditional Lunar New Year gift her boss placed in her hands in February, the Chinese character for happiness and luck gleaming from the paper. She opened it to find just $20.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="131" data-total-count="34222" itemprop="articleBody">She quit on March 8. Her boss said nothing; one colleague hugged her goodbye. After 10 months she had made about $10,000, she said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="60" data-total-count="34282" itemprop="articleBody">Last month, she found a $65-a-day job at another nail salon.</p><button class="button comments-button  theme-speech-bubble" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-21">
</button>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="79" data-total-count="34361" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-21">By then, her parents had also found work. Her father is a cook at a restaurant.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="51" data-total-count="34412" itemprop="articleBody">Her mother? She became a manicurist, for $30 a day.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="145" data-total-count="34557" itemprop="articleBody"><em><strong>Read </strong><strong><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/11/nyregion/nail-salon-workers-in-nyc-face-hazardous-chemicals.html">Perfect Nails, Poisoned Workers</a>,</strong> the second article in this series, which examines the potential health risks endured by nail salon workers.</em></p>
        
                                <div id="addendums" class="addendums">
    <div class="story-addendum story-content theme-correction">
        <strong> Correction: May 7, 2015 </strong> <br/>
    	A map with an earlier version of this article omitted two Starbucks locations on the Upper East Side. In addition to stores at East 96th Street and Madison Avenue; East 92nd Street and Third Avenue; and East 90th Street and First Avenue, there are Starbucks establishments at East 87th Street and Third Avenue and East 96th Street and Lexington Avenue. The map also showed an incorrect location for one of the stores. It is at East 87th Street and Lexington Avenue, not East 86th Street and Lexington.    </div>
</div>
        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
                <div class="story-notes"><p>Reporting was contributed by Sarah Cohen, Jiha Ham, Jeanne Li, Yuhan Liu, Julie Turkewitz, Isvett Verde, Yeong-Ung Yang and Heyang Zhang, and research by Susan C. Beachy.<br /><br /></p></div>
        
        
        <p class="story-print-citation">A version of this article appears in print on May 10, 2015, on page A1 of the <span itemprop="printEdition">New York edition</span> with the headline: The High Price of Pretty Nails    . <span class="story-footer-links">  <span><a href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?contentID=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2015%2F05%2F10%2Fnyregion%2Fat-nail-salons-in-nyc-manicurists-are-underpaid-and-unprotected.html&publisherName=The+New+York+Times&publication=nytimes.com&token=&orderBeanReset=true&postType=&wordCount=5979&title=The+Price+of+Nice+Nails&publicationDate=May+7%2C+2015&author=By Sarah Maslin Nir" target="_blank">Order Reprints</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span>  <span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/pages/todayspaper/index.html" target="_blank">Today's Paper</a><span class="pipe">|</span></span><span><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/subscriptions/Multiproduct/lp839RF.html?campaignId=48JQY" target="_blank">Subscribe</a></span>
</span>
</p>
    </div><!-- close story-meta -->
    </footer>

            </div><!-- close story-body -->
</article>

            <li class="wide-viewport-item last-item"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/content/help/rights/sale/terms-of-sale.html">Terms of Sale</a></li>
         </ul>
    </nav>
    <nav class="last-nav">
        <ul>
            <li><a href="http://spiderbites.nytimes.com">Site Map</a></li>

    </nav>
</footer>
        </div><!-- close page -->
    </div><!-- close shell -->
    <script>
require(['foundation/main'], function () {
    require(['article/main']);
    require(['jquery/nyt', 'foundation/views/page-manager'], function ($, pageManager) {
        if (window.location.search.indexOf('disable_tagx') > 0) {
            return;
        }
        $(document).ready(function () {
            require(['http://static01.nyt.com/bi/js/tagx/tagx.js'], function () {
                pageManager.trackingFireEventQueue();
            });
        });
    });
});

    theme-minimal

    <header class="story-header interactive-header">
                        <div class="story-meta">
                            <button class="button comments-button  theme-kicker" data-skip-to-para-id="">
</button>
                                                <h1 class="story-heading interactive-headline" itemprop="headline">A New Whitney</h1>
            
            <div class="story-meta-footer interactive-meta-footer">
                <div class="interactive-byline">
    <p class="byline-dateline"><span class="byline last-byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/michael_kimmelman/index.html">By <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/michael_kimmelman/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by MICHAEL KIMMELMAN"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="MICHAEL KIMMELMAN" itemprop="name" data-twitter-handle="kimmelman">MICHAEL KIMMELMAN</span></a></span>	<time class="dateline" datetime="2015-04-19" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-04-19">APRIL 19, 2015</time>
    </p>
</div>
                 <p class="interactive-leadin summary">
            <span class="summary-text">No longer a fortress in an uneasy city, the Whitney Museum of American Art opens itself up to a changed New York, a glittery emblem of new urban capital signaling a definitive shift in the city’s social geography.</span>
    
        		                                </p>
            </div><!-- close story-meta-footer -->

.story-footer p {
  font-style: italic;
  margin: 1em auto;
  font-size: 1rem;;
  line-height: 1.4375rem;
  font-weight: 400;
  font-family: georgia, serif;
}
  .videodueno-graf {
    max-width: 650px;
    font-size: 22px;
    line-height: 32px;
    margin: 5em auto 1em;
  }
  .video {
    width: 100%;
    height: 300vh;
    max-width: none;
    position: relative;
    overflow: hidden;
    margin: 5em 0;
  }
    .video-part {
      height: 100vh;
      position: relative;
    }
      .video-container {
        position: fixed;
        top: 0; left: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0;
        z-index: 0;
        display: none;
        opacity: 0;
        z-index: 2;
        transition: opacity 2s;
        -webkit-transition: opacity 2s;
      }
        .stuck .video-container {
          position: absolute;
        }

          font: 17px/30px arial, sans-serif;
          position: absolute;
          width: 11px;
          top: 50%;
          right: 20px;
          color: #000;
          transition: opacity 3s;
          -webkit-transition: opacity 3s;
        }
